BEGIN NOW Although a tiny spot along Lake Merritt, Grand Lake Kitchen is truly a gem! I stopped in for a late breakfast/brunch and I would highly recommend it. END
BEGIN NOW  Although it's tempting to sit inside at the counter and watch the chefs work their magic, the umbrellaed outdoor patio gives a beautiful (although a touch away) view of beautiful Lake Merritt. END
BEGIN NOW  Although we visited on a Monday late morning (note: they're closed all day Tuesdays!), there was a steady stream of people waiting for tables throughout our visit. END
BEGIN NOW We started with a bottled rose lemonade (although it isn't made in house, I always order a Fentimans soda when available) and a hibiscus cleanse (more sour than I expected but different in a good way). END
BEGIN NOW  From there we ordered the dungeness crab appetizer, served on toasted bread with avocado and topped with fresh greens. END
BEGIN NOW  This was truly a spectacular dish, the crab was amazing and the flavors combined perfectly and were crisp and fresh. END
BEGIN NOW  Perfect appetizer to split between two people. END
BEGIN NOW  For our main course we ordered the Italian sandwich, which they cut in the kitchen for us and served on two plates, a nice touch, with a pickled vegetable on the side. END
BEGIN NOW  The ACME bread that it was served on (as most of the sandwiches are served on) is spectacular, sandwiches delicious meats, lettuce, tomato and swiss cheese. END
BEGIN NOW  You will not be disappointed with this pick from the menu!. END
BEGIN NOW Grand Lake Kitchen is a restaurant that, if I lived in the area, I would return to over and over again. END
BEGIN NOW  Everything coming out of the kitchen looked delicious and I've heard from others positive things about so many dishes. END
BEGIN NOW  It's a place where it'd be easy to explore the menu and always want to order something new. END
BEGIN NOW  They also sell a variety of specialty products in the restaurant, including Durham, NC made Big Spoon peanut butter (shout out to my home city!) One note: they don't accept American Express here. END

BEGIN NOW  This is one of the best burgers I've ever had. END

BEGIN NOW  the bun is somewhere between sourdough and a pastry. END
BEGIN NOW  It is remarkable. END

BEGIN NOW I learned a very important lesson during my visit to Portal Restaurant: never visit an establishment that has multiple signs posted on the front of the building advertising the need and higher for chefs. END

BEGIN NOW We ordered sharing plates for four people which included:. END
BEGIN NOW *ricotta bites: as delicious as they sound, fried on the outside, cheesy on the inside. END
BEGIN NOW  Portion came with four bites and a marinara sauce (sauce to bites ratio was off, request more sauce if you ever see your waitress!). END
BEGIN NOW *cesar salad: OK, covered with parmesan cheese and house-made croutons, large portion but lacked flavor and dressing to lettuce ratio was off. END
BEGIN NOW *brussels sprouts: Good, but damn, I feel like a good home-chef should be able to whip up some taste brussels, and these aren't any better than what I can make a home. END
BEGIN NOW *garbage bread: Best part of the meal, hands down! Tasty, flavorful, crispy and chewy: this is their signature dish. END

BEGIN NOW A new and not-so-much longer hidden gem in Oakland's Laurel District that is the perfect place for a weekend brunch on one of those sunny days that Oakland is famous for! I am a real fan of this great neighborhood diner where everything is homemade from their pastries to their jams in addition to their classic dishes for brunch. END
BEGIN NOW  And Sequoia Diner lives up the hype that's been expressed from so many reviews and images posted from my fellow Yelpers!. END
BEGIN NOW I actually found out about Sequoia Diner due to the fact it seemed like it was on Yelp's "New Businesses in East Bay" for an eternity! It actually opened about a year ago, replacing the long-standing Full House Cafe, by a local husband and wife duo who wanted to stay loyal to the neighborhood with their seasonal brunch classics served all morning until mid-afternoon. END
BEGIN NOW  There is so much buzz for Sequoia Diner that wait times can be quite long for brunch and parking on MacArthur Avenue and the surrounding area can be quite dicey. END
BEGIN NOW  So plan ahead it you don't mind waiting. END
BEGIN NOW  Luckily, I had friends who were eager enough to get there early and put our names down and patient enough for me to get there just a wee bit late. END
BEGIN NOW Once we were sat in their patent leather booths, we each knew what we wanted. END
BEGIN NOW  (I had been doing enough research from my fellow Yelper's images and reviews to know what to order and what to pass up. END
BEGIN NOW ) We knew we all had to get the highly-recommended Pecan Sticky Buns and at $3. END
BEGIN NOW 75 each it's a good deal, so much so, the three of us ordered two buns to share. END
BEGIN NOW  I found them not too sweet or sticky with the perfect amount of cinnamon, sugar and topped with an abundance of chopped pecans. END
BEGIN NOW  It's a perfect accompaniment to your coffee. END
BEGIN NOW As for my main dish, I knew that some Sequoia Diner plates were heavier than others, but I also wanted to taste some of the best and unique dishes that they have to offer to get a read on how they prepare their meals here. END
BEGIN NOW  So I went with the Country Breakfast with its biscuit and gravy, collared greens, hash browns and two eggs made to order. END
BEGIN NOW  Although obviously heavy, my dish was solid, I especially loved the creamy gravy, warm biscuit, and hash browns. END
BEGIN NOW  You could tell with the first bite how much homemade goodness was put into your meal. END
BEGIN NOW  Despite being constantly busy, the service for the most part was attentive and there was constant turnover of the tables and counter-tops, made the flow of service that much more pleasant. END
BEGIN NOW Sequoia Diner is your classic mom-and-pop owned and operated American breakfast joint with modern day sustainable and locavore sensibilities. END
BEGIN NOW  Their eclectic menu makes me want to come back for more, everything sounds so familiar yet so unique that it seems like you can't go wrong. END
BEGIN NOW  I can't wait to return one day to see how Sequoia Diner continues to build upon their success in a loyal and foodie loving neighborhood. END
BEGIN NOW I never loved brunch much, always made me feel comatose and heavy afterwards. END
BEGIN NOW   SD has the sweetspot between comfort and fresh. END
BEGIN NOW If you're ordering to-go, it's a good idea to call ahead, it took upwards of 30 minutes to get my order, there isn't much seating for those waiting, I ordered a coffee to hold me over while waiting, comes in super cute beige/brown cups, reminds me of the 70s and 80s. END
BEGIN NOW   Such a pleasant throwback to a simpler time. END
BEGIN NOW LOVED the Red Flannel Hash. END
BEGIN NOW   Perfectly poached eggs, kraut to cut the richness, cubes of al dente beets and potatoes. END
BEGIN NOW   They don't take substitutions. END
BEGIN NOW   I wanted to swap out one of the eggs for some chard, but had to order it separately. END
BEGIN NOW   Sour cream was mysteriously left off - perfect, I was going to omit it anyways. END

BEGIN NOW I'd had this bookmarked for a while, but ventured into the Laurel District in East Oakland for the first time this morning. END
BEGIN NOW  I was surprised to see that none of my trusted East Bay Yelpers had reviewed this place but was excited to give it a whirl. END
BEGIN NOW We arrived around 8:30 and found the place mostly full, but were able to grab the last available booth with no wait. END
BEGIN NOW  It has that diner charm, with a long bar counter and several booths along the wall. END
BEGIN NOW  This isn't the place to bring a large group, but it is perfectly cozy for 2 or 4. END
BEGIN NOW  There are several adorable waitresses that were super friendly, greeting you on the way in and out, and keeping the coffee coming. END
BEGIN NOW  I loved the positive vibe. END
BEGIN NOW I like that they keep the menu relatively simple, with several classics, and a few twists. END
BEGIN NOW  No kids menu here, per se, but my boys were happy with their pastries. END
BEGIN NOW a pecan roll and the strawberry cream cheese danish. END
BEGIN NOW  They stood on their own as a small breakfast, but would be equally nice as a shared starter while you wait on the main event. END
BEGIN NOW I was thrilled with the mushroom and spinach scramble which, like their other egg dishes, come with some perfectly cooked and seasoned potatoes, some excellent sourdough toast, and a small rocket salad. END
BEGIN NOW  Seemingly simple, but it leaves you wondering why you can't do 'em that perfect at home. END
BEGIN NOW The Highwire brewed coffee wasn't my favorite, but it did the trick and my cup was never empty or cold. END
BEGIN NOW All in all, a real winner that will get added to the Sunday rotation!. END
BEGIN NOW I was sold when I saw that they have Pecan Sticky Buns!  I love sticky buns and for some reason, it's really hard to find it in the Bay Area. END
BEGIN NOW   I used to get them at Berkeley Bowl, but they don't have it anymore. END
BEGIN NOW   I'm also very particular about my sticky buns. END

BEGIN NOW   $3. END
BEGIN NOW 75 for one is quite reasonable. END
BEGIN NOW   It's a nice size, so two people can easily share one. END

BEGIN NOW  I've never been to Laurel before, but it's one of those transitional, culturally diverse neighborhoods where you could have a cup of artisan coffee one minute but you feel a need to keep staring at your car while it's parked on the street. END
BEGIN NOW  It's a Temescal-in-waiting, and if it does become the East Bay's next gourmet ghetto, you can thank the husband-and-wife team of Andrew Vennari and Sequoia Broderson who opened this comfy-cozy spot which drew quite a few for breakfast on Saturday morning (photo: bit. END

BEGIN NOW There is outdoor seating in the front of the restaurant and they are dog friendly, yay!! My friend asked the server for some chicken for the dog and (although it took a while. END
BEGIN NOW ) he came back with perfectly grilled slices of chicken (4 bucks a breast). END

BEGIN NOW This is a cute, trendy spot in Uptown Oakland where customers ranging from college students to older, more mature patrons come to dine. END
BEGIN NOW  It is a tiny restaurant, but there is seating both inside and outside, and the decorations are spot-on. END
BEGIN NOW  The menu changes for lunch and dinner, and are limited to about 5-7 offerings, and is on the pricey side. END
BEGIN NOW I came here once for brunch and another time for dinner. END
BEGIN NOW My favorite is the yonsei oysters, which includes salmon roe and uni on the half shell, a perfect Asian fusion dish. END
BEGIN NOW  They taste fresh and complex. END
BEGIN NOW  One second you taste the salty juices of the roe, then you taste the sweet briny freshness of the uni, followed by the cool ocean flavor of the oysters. END
BEGIN NOW  The portions are a bit small but they are definitely delicious. END
BEGIN NOW For brunch, I had the braised pork belly benedict. END
BEGIN NOW  The pork belly was cooked perfectly, crunchy and tender at the right places. END
BEGIN NOW  The hollandaise sauce was the right amount of creamy and citrusy. END
BEGIN NOW  I liked that it was a well-executed twist on a classic brunch platter. END
BEGIN NOW However, I did not like the dinner dishes as much. END
BEGIN NOW  They seemed a bit too average for the price you pay. END
BEGIN NOW  Granted, I'm sure they use the most high quality and the freshest ingredients, but at $19 for a plate of pasta and $22 for clams, I sort of expect something out of this world. END
BEGIN NOW The soba bucatini is very tomatoey but tastes just a bit better than the average pasta, though the green beans do add a nice crunch. END
BEGIN NOW  The manila clams were yummy and it came with a deep-fried vegetable that paired well with the seafood tomato sauce. END
BEGIN NOW  However, I felt the prices were too high for what my bf and I got. END
BEGIN NOW Overall, this is a nice little date spot, but much more so for brunch. END
BEGIN NOW  They have a bar and serve all types of alcohol, so it's great for boozey brunch. END
BEGIN NOW Any chance to try a new brunch place is gladly taken - #brunchsohard! We heard this place has a better brunch menu than dinner. END
BEGIN NOW  They have a very small location but there's apparently more seating next door! You can make reservations too, so definitely plan ahead. END
BEGIN NOW Everything on their menu was tempting - American brunch fare with a Korean twist, what better combination could there be!? I just had to go for the kimchee fried rice with shoyu eggs and pork belly. END
BEGIN NOW  Tender, flavorful, spicy and sweet. END
BEGIN NOW every bite was perfect. END
BEGIN NOW  We also got to try the donuts with butterscotch cream (it should be a sin to have this for breakfast) and the cinnamon challah toast with jam (how is this so soft?!). END
BEGIN NOW  I had a bite of their famous fried chicken and biscuits for whatever room was left in my stomach and wow it was not your typical chicken and biscuits!. END
BEGIN NOW Based on my experience today, you will not be disappointed no matter what you order. END
BEGIN NOW  Wish we had this place closer to home. END
BEGIN NOW I'd be ordering that kimchee fried rice on a weekly basis. END
BEGIN NOW I went with a Yonsei Oyster and the Buttermilk Fried Chicken--both were good, but both items are way overpriced which disallows me from giving this place anymore than 3 stars. END
BEGIN NOW  Everything else about the experience here was outstanding except the $23 chicken that didn't even come with a carb on the side. END
BEGIN NOW  That dish is worth $13-$15 at most. END
BEGIN NOW  It was literally just some fried chicken (sure, dredged in their signature marinade of buttermilk, soy sauce, and potato starch), some asparagus, and chrysanthemum salad with vinegar. END
BEGIN NOW  The chicken was juicy and tasty but it wasn't even a decent size--was still hungry after. END
BEGIN NOW  You can argue that this one dish alone isn't supposed to fill you up however I think that the very essence of fried chicken is a comfort food that serves the purpose of filling you up and if someone wants to make it extra special, he/she can do that, but he/she doesn't need to make it so fancy it becomes small and too expensive. END
BEGIN NOW  It's fried chicken, how much extra does your buttermilk and soy sauce cost? This isn't Napa where you're surrounded by million dollar wineries. END
BEGIN NOW  I can understand overpriced oysters, but $23 fried chicken in Oakland? You've got to be kidding me. END
BEGIN NOW Since I wasn't fully satisfied, I had to go to Belly down the street which is where I should've went to in the first place. END
BEGIN NOW  Literally, if they just added something like mashed or scalloped potatoes, this dish would be on point. END
BEGIN NOW  I'm not sure why everyone raves about it. END
BEGIN NOW  Furthermore, I've never complained about negative space on a dish but even from the consumer point of view, the dish didn't come together well looks-wise. END
BEGIN NOW  It'll leave you hanging like, "where's the rest of my food?" The oyster was pretty delicious, but not worth $5. END
BEGIN NOW So, I honestly would recommend checking out Hopscotch and I want to come back someday to give it another try, but please do yourself a favor and refrain from ordering that fried chicken--you're better off going to 'insert-your-favorite-fast-food-fried-chicken-joint here'. END

BEGIN NOW I have to say Hopscotch has a pretty delicious brunch! This was my first time brunching in Oakland as opposed to SF, and it was pretty positive overall. END
BEGIN NOW  The setup of the restaurant is a little confusing, as there are two separate rooms separated by a convenience store in the middle. END
BEGIN NOW  We dined in the second room, which I actually thought had a nicer and more spacious layout. END
BEGIN NOW We started off the meal with some mimosas and the Donuts and Butterscotch Cream. END

BEGIN NOW drips:. END
BEGIN NOW In a world overrun with Starbucks, Peet's and Keurig machines that you have to decalcify every 2 minutes (you don't know my struggle so you don't feel my hustle!), a good cup of coffee has become a luxury that too many of us don't get too experience often enough. END
BEGIN NOW  But look no further! Sip on without the shame of knowing your joe was sourced by underpaid laborers and upheld by unfair labor practices! Dunk a delicious donut hole in that cup and know that pastry was made with wholehearted love and passion by women who support fair business practices and use their small business to uplift their community!. END
BEGIN NOW I love everything about Mamacita's, and please believe that the coffee, lavender lemonade and yummy donut kebabs are just the beginning. END
BEGIN NOW  The owners, Shana and Renee, grind super hard for theirs and employ and educate young women in high school on the ins and outs of business ownership along the way by offering opportunities to keep kids occupied and focused. END
BEGIN NOW  They serve up Red Bay Coffee, keeping it fresh, local and delicious while giving back to the hood whenever they can. END

BEGIN NOW   Auntie charges a 15% surcharge to help pay for the entire staff. END
BEGIN NOW   You may also leave and additional amount that will go directly to your server. END
BEGIN NOW   And like a good Aunt, she has broken down what the extra 3% or 5% for your server would be. END
BEGIN NOW   You read this coming into the restaurant, you read it again at the table and on your tab. END
BEGIN NOW The cost of doing business is just that. END
BEGIN NOW   Whatever you have to pay to keep your place staffed well should be built into the cost of your meals, not let the patron work on supplementing your payroll. END
BEGIN NOW   What will we see next?  PG&E goes up on gas so there is another surcharge to read about if we want hot food or to see the food on the table?. END

BEGIN NOW District isn't a restaurant. END
BEGIN NOW   It's a wine bar with food. END
BEGIN NOW   We failed to know this. END
BEGIN NOW Their menu consists of small plates and pizzas. END
BEGIN NOW   The bf and I ordered six dishes and that was too much. END

BEGIN NOW   If not, order as you go. END
BEGIN NOW MUST TRY:. END
BEGIN NOW The two standout dishes of the night were the tempura avocado and the sliced hanger steak. END
BEGIN NOW   The tempura avocado had a light and crispy exterior, topped with chili lime salt (which was phenomenal), and served with a roasted jalapeno aioli sauce for dipping. END
BEGIN NOW   The hanger steak was so tender that it melts in your mouth. END
BEGIN NOW   The topping was that it was served with chimichurri sauce. END
BEGIN NOW OTHER FOOD:. END
BEGIN NOW *The raw oysters were medium size and served with a mignonette sauce and fresh horseradish. END
BEGIN NOW   They do have $1 oysters (opposed to $2. END
BEGIN NOW 50 each) during happy hour (weekdays 4-6pm). END
BEGIN NOW *The steak tartare was okay. END
BEGIN NOW   The bf wasn't a big fan as it was tangier than other places. END
BEGIN NOW   One of the biggest mistakes with the dish was the egg. END
BEGIN NOW   Unlike most places that serve it with a raw egg on top, District's version cooks their egg. END
BEGIN NOW   My egg was more cooked than in pictures I've seen on Yelp and lacked that yolky gooiness. END
BEGIN NOW *The margherita pizza had a nice thin crust and was perfect for sharing. END
BEGIN NOW   It was topped with tomatoes, mozzarella and basil. END
BEGIN NOW   It was good but it needed more tomatoes or tomato sauce. END
BEGIN NOW Service was nice but staff was often missing so it took a long time getting what we needed. END
BEGIN NOW   There was a bit of a timing issue with food arrival. END
BEGIN NOW   The pace in the beginning was good as we had food in front of us but not to the point of taking up all table room). END
BEGIN NOW   There was so much time between the last couple dishes that food had settled and we were too full. END
BEGIN NOW Depending on the size of your party, make a reservation on Opentable. END
BEGIN NOW   If reservations aren't made, seating is free for all which we lucked out with. END
BEGIN NOW   District has a limited number of reservations because there is a limited amount of seating. END
BEGIN NOW   Though it's a big place, most of the area is taken for bar seating and lounge areas. END
BEGIN NOW WHAT TO KNOW:. END

BEGIN NOW During my first year of working in Oakland, I would, on average, about once a week, take a lunchtime walk from our office at City Center to Jack London Square, usually approaching via Chinatown and Webster Street while returning via Old Town and Washington Street. END
BEGIN NOW  In the latter area, I've been to Pacific Coast Brewing Company a couple of times, I've glanced at the used bookstore, and have made frequent passages through Swan's Market. END
BEGIN NOW  Also noticed have been a handful of somewhat trendy-looking bars, just awaiting for me to make an appearance. END
BEGIN NOW Finally, as it often happens, I wind up at a wonderful new location almost by accident. END
BEGIN NOW  A couple of weeks ago we were supposed to meet at another bar about a half block away. END
BEGIN NOW  For whatever reason, however, that location was not open when it said it would be. END
BEGIN NOW  Its loss and The District's gain. END
BEGIN NOW  Or, more precisely, our gain - we now have a reliable standby to go to after a day of putting up with the powers that be. END
BEGIN NOW  Comfy seats at right angles with room for small plates to share, the environment is just made for socializing - public but not too loud; active but with the ability to move around freely. END
BEGIN NOW  Plus the place has a good selection of brews, hard alcohol, and after work food - I recommend the shrimp pizza with chorizo, with a Raging Bitch to wash it down. END

BEGIN NOW  The food is a bit hit or miss, though. END
BEGIN NOW  My first time here I got the breakfast bagel sandwich and it was utter bliss, and everyone in my group (we were a party of 9) were served speedily and everyone was happy. END
BEGIN NOW  The next time I came, almost every person had a problem with their order (the wrong sides were brought out, goat cheese was missing from a goat cheese omelet). END

BEGIN NOW   He and Larry had coffee. END

BEGIN NOW Located in the same building in, or at least next door to, a senior living facility, the Terrace Room offers a gorgeous view of Lake Merritt from the west, which means that most of the time you won't be blinded by the sun like you would from the other side of the lake. END

BEGIN NOW Dogwood is a solid bar in a happening stretch of town, right near the Fox Theatre where Telegraph branches off Broadway towards the north. END
BEGIN NOW  There's a good variety of tasty cocktails to choose from, and the bartenders are knowledgeable and and friendly enough to make anything you want. END
BEGIN NOW  What's more, there's a decent menu of munchies, like the totally delicious cubanito sandwich I tried. END
BEGIN NOW  While the interior might feel a bit dark as you walk in, you'll adjust quickly to the cozy yet retro-sleek ambience. END
BEGIN NOW Also, you have to give the owners credit for sticking it out here over the years. END
BEGIN NOW  Dogwood is located on such a busy street corner that drunk drivers have crashed into it twice, while rioters have also smashed the windows twice. END
BEGIN NOW  Nevertheless, the area is on the way up and  the owners have bounced back each time. END
BEGIN NOW  Judging by the healthy crowds this place gets, it looks like the community has embraced Dogwood as well. END

BEGIN NOW Braised oxtail sando!!!!!. END
BEGIN NOW I was able to sample there Braised oxtail sandwich and let me say I will be back for more, not oily, not fatty, near perfection on a toasted bun. END
BEGIN NOW  The sandwich on a whole was a tad small, especially if you are sharing, but the meat was tender and flavorful, not to salty, more or less all around perfect on meat to bun proportion. END
BEGIN NOW I also sampled the bone marrow dish, no skimming on this dish, full heavy amount of bone marrow on the bone, like most places that offer this dish you are scraping the bone to get every last bit, here the marrow was heavy, oily, thick consistency, throw it on some toasted bread that is offered and it is delicious, you can dip the bread in the sauce found underneath the bone, ohh man sooo good,. BEGIN NOW   Although it's tempting to sit inside at the counter and watch the chefs work their magic, the umbrellaed outdoor patio gives a beautiful (although a touch away) view of beautiful Lake Merritt. END

BEGIN NOW  We started with a bottled rose lemonade (although it isn't made in house, I always order a Fentimans soda when available) and a hibiscus cleanse (more sour than I expected but different in a good way). END

BEGIN NOW   This was truly a spectacular dish, the crab was amazing and the flavors combined perfectly and were crisp and fresh. END

BEGIN NOW  Chop Bar is the good Oakland, the kind you want to show off to your friends. END
BEGIN NOW  It's located in a cool loft space in Jack London, within walking distance from the Blue Bottle flagship location. END
BEGIN NOW   The wait on a Sunday afternoon teeters around 20 mins, which isn't all that bad in comparison to some spots in San Francisco. END
BEGIN NOW  The menu features all kinds of new American and California inspired plates. END
BEGIN NOW   Their burger is a serious force to be reckoned with. END
BEGIN NOW   This is one of the best burgers I've ever had. END
BEGIN NOW   Let me lay this out for you. END
BEGIN NOW   the bun is somewhere between sourdough and a pastry. END
BEGIN NOW   It is remarkable. END
BEGIN NOW   The hamburger patty is so thick and so juicy and as you eat this thing, the juices dribble out and the soft part of the bun soaks it up. END
BEGIN NOW   Thick, hickory smoked slices of bacon and avocado adorn this creation. END
BEGIN NOW   Make sure to add cheese too because, holy crap, the melted swiss cheese on this thing was delicious. END
BEGIN NOW   I asked for medium rare and received a very well done patty, but I was too hungry to do anything about it. END
BEGIN NOW   Kind of a bummer, so make sure your waiter knows you're not playing around. END
BEGIN NOW  They only have 4 beers on tap, none of which is a pilsner, and all their taps were broken when I went. END

BEGIN NOW  *ricotta bites: as delicious as they sound, fried on the outside, cheesy on the inside. END

BEGIN NOW  A new and not-so-much longer hidden gem in Oakland's Laurel District that is the perfect place for a weekend brunch on one of those sunny days that Oakland is famous for! I am a real fan of this great neighborhood diner where everything is homemade from their pastries to their jams in addition to their classic dishes for brunch. END
BEGIN NOW   And Sequoia Diner lives up the hype that's been expressed from so many reviews and images posted from my fellow Yelpers!. END
BEGIN NOW  I actually found out about Sequoia Diner due to the fact it seemed like it was on Yelp's "New Businesses in East Bay" for an eternity! It actually opened about a year ago, replacing the long-standing Full House Cafe, by a local husband and wife duo who wanted to stay loyal to the neighborhood with their seasonal brunch classics served all morning until mid-afternoon. END
BEGIN NOW   There is so much buzz for Sequoia Diner that wait times can be quite long for brunch and parking on MacArthur Avenue and the surrounding area can be quite dicey. END
BEGIN NOW   So plan ahead it you don't mind waiting. END
BEGIN NOW   Luckily, I had friends who were eager enough to get there early and put our names down and patient enough for me to get there just a wee bit late. END
BEGIN NOW  Once we were sat in their patent leather booths, we each knew what we wanted. END

BEGIN NOW  ) We knew we all had to get the highly-recommended Pecan Sticky Buns and at $3. END
BEGIN NOW  75 each it's a good deal, so much so, the three of us ordered two buns to share. END
BEGIN NOW   I found them not too sweet or sticky with the perfect amount of cinnamon, sugar and topped with an abundance of chopped pecans. END
BEGIN NOW   It's a perfect accompaniment to your coffee. END
BEGIN NOW  As for my main dish, I knew that some Sequoia Diner plates were heavier than others, but I also wanted to taste some of the best and unique dishes that they have to offer to get a read on how they prepare their meals here. END
BEGIN NOW   So I went with the Country Breakfast with its biscuit and gravy, collared greens, hash browns and two eggs made to order. END
BEGIN NOW   Although obviously heavy, my dish was solid, I especially loved the creamy gravy, warm biscuit, and hash browns. END
BEGIN NOW   You could tell with the first bite how much homemade goodness was put into your meal. END
BEGIN NOW   Despite being constantly busy, the service for the most part was attentive and there was constant turnover of the tables and counter-tops, made the flow of service that much more pleasant. END
BEGIN NOW  Sequoia Diner is your classic mom-and-pop owned and operated American breakfast joint with modern day sustainable and locavore sensibilities. END
BEGIN NOW   Their eclectic menu makes me want to come back for more, everything sounds so familiar yet so unique that it seems like you can't go wrong. END
BEGIN NOW   I can't wait to return one day to see how Sequoia Diner continues to build upon their success in a loyal and foodie loving neighborhood. END

BEGIN NOW    SD has the sweetspot between comfort and fresh. END
BEGIN NOW  If you're ordering to-go, it's a good idea to call ahead, it took upwards of 30 minutes to get my order, there isn't much seating for those waiting, I ordered a coffee to hold me over while waiting, comes in super cute beige/brown cups, reminds me of the 70s and 80s. END
BEGIN NOW    Such a pleasant throwback to a simpler time. END

BEGIN NOW  This is a cute, trendy spot in Uptown Oakland where customers ranging from college students to older, more mature patrons come to dine. END
BEGIN NOW   It is a tiny restaurant, but there is seating both inside and outside, and the decorations are spot-on. END
BEGIN NOW   The menu changes for lunch and dinner, and are limited to about 5-7 offerings, and is on the pricey side. END
BEGIN NOW  I came here once for brunch and another time for dinner. END
BEGIN NOW  My favorite is the yonsei oysters, which includes salmon roe and uni on the half shell, a perfect Asian fusion dish. END
BEGIN NOW   They taste fresh and complex. END
BEGIN NOW   One second you taste the salty juices of the roe, then you taste the sweet briny freshness of the uni, followed by the cool ocean flavor of the oysters. END
BEGIN NOW   The portions are a bit small but they are definitely delicious. END
BEGIN NOW  For brunch, I had the braised pork belly benedict. END
BEGIN NOW   The pork belly was cooked perfectly, crunchy and tender at the right places. END
BEGIN NOW   The hollandaise sauce was the right amount of creamy and citrusy. END
BEGIN NOW   I liked that it was a well-executed twist on a classic brunch platter. END
BEGIN NOW  However, I did not like the dinner dishes as much. END
BEGIN NOW   They seemed a bit too average for the price you pay. END
BEGIN NOW   Granted, I'm sure they use the most high quality and the freshest ingredients, but at $19 for a plate of pasta and $22 for clams, I sort of expect something out of this world. END
BEGIN NOW  The soba bucatini is very tomatoey but tastes just a bit better than the average pasta, though the green beans do add a nice crunch. END
BEGIN NOW   The manila clams were yummy and it came with a deep-fried vegetable that paired well with the seafood tomato sauce. END
BEGIN NOW   However, I felt the prices were too high for what my bf and I got. END
BEGIN NOW  Overall, this is a nice little date spot, but much more so for brunch. END
BEGIN NOW   They have a bar and serve all types of alcohol, so it's great for boozey brunch. END
BEGIN NOW  Any chance to try a new brunch place is gladly taken - #brunchsohard! We heard this place has a better brunch menu than dinner. END
BEGIN NOW   They have a very small location but there's apparently more seating next door! You can make reservations too, so definitely plan ahead. END
BEGIN NOW  Everything on their menu was tempting - American brunch fare with a Korean twist, what better combination could there be!? I just had to go for the kimchee fried rice with shoyu eggs and pork belly. END
BEGIN NOW   Tender, flavorful, spicy and sweet. END
BEGIN NOW  every bite was perfect. END
BEGIN NOW   We also got to try the donuts with butterscotch cream (it should be a sin to have this for breakfast) and the cinnamon challah toast with jam (how is this so soft?!). END
BEGIN NOW   I had a bite of their famous fried chicken and biscuits for whatever room was left in my stomach and wow it was not your typical chicken and biscuits!. END
BEGIN NOW  Based on my experience today, you will not be disappointed no matter what you order. END
BEGIN NOW   Wish we had this place closer to home. END
BEGIN NOW  I'd be ordering that kimchee fried rice on a weekly basis. END
BEGIN NOW  I went with a Yonsei Oyster and the Buttermilk Fried Chicken--both were good, but both items are way overpriced which disallows me from giving this place anymore than 3 stars. END
BEGIN NOW   Everything else about the experience here was outstanding except the $23 chicken that didn't even come with a carb on the side. END
BEGIN NOW   That dish is worth $13-$15 at most. END
BEGIN NOW   It was literally just some fried chicken (sure, dredged in their signature marinade of buttermilk, soy sauce, and potato starch), some asparagus, and chrysanthemum salad with vinegar. END
BEGIN NOW   The chicken was juicy and tasty but it wasn't even a decent size--was still hungry after. END
BEGIN NOW   You can argue that this one dish alone isn't supposed to fill you up however I think that the very essence of fried chicken is a comfort food that serves the purpose of filling you up and if someone wants to make it extra special, he/she can do that, but he/she doesn't need to make it so fancy it becomes small and too expensive. END
BEGIN NOW   It's fried chicken, how much extra does your buttermilk and soy sauce cost? This isn't Napa where you're surrounded by million dollar wineries. END
BEGIN NOW   I can understand overpriced oysters, but $23 fried chicken in Oakland? You've got to be kidding me. END
BEGIN NOW  Since I wasn't fully satisfied, I had to go to Belly down the street which is where I should've went to in the first place. END
BEGIN NOW   Literally, if they just added something like mashed or scalloped potatoes, this dish would be on point. END
BEGIN NOW   I'm not sure why everyone raves about it. END
BEGIN NOW   Furthermore, I've never complained about negative space on a dish but even from the consumer point of view, the dish didn't come together well looks-wise. END
BEGIN NOW   It'll leave you hanging like, "where's the rest of my food?" The oyster was pretty delicious, but not worth $5. END
BEGIN NOW  So, I honestly would recommend checking out Hopscotch and I want to come back someday to give it another try, but please do yourself a favor and refrain from ordering that fried chicken--you're better off going to 'insert-your-favorite-fast-food-fried-chicken-joint here'. END

BEGIN NOW   The setup of the restaurant is a little confusing, as there are two separate rooms separated by a convenience store in the middle. END

BEGIN NOW   The main room where the hostess is located is quite small and I was wondering if we were going to fit. END
BEGIN NOW   After a very short walk to their "annex" as they called it, we were pleased to find more larger tables and room for our party of four. END
BEGIN NOW   Both rooms were sparsely decorated and appeared that the building was from the early 1900s, it had a cozy feel. END

BEGIN NOW   The Scotch was served neat with both water and ice on the side. END
BEGIN NOW   I popped a single rock into the scotch to open it up a bit and proceeded to sip back and forth off the two enjoying how the flavors played off each other in harmony. END
BEGIN NOW  The menu is spartan with only 5 entree offerings and 6 starter options. END

BEGIN NOW   Now beef tongue is not usually something I seek out but I was feeling adventurous. END
BEGIN NOW   I took a chance and ordered it medium rare on the waitresses suggestion and unfortunately is came out about as rare as I've ever seen a burger. END
BEGIN NOW   I still ate it and it was tasty but I learned my lesson, medium for burgers, medium rare for steaks. END
BEGIN NOW   I added the house cured bacon and some cheddar cheese to my burger and that put it @ $20. END
BEGIN NOW   The $20 burger was served with some house made kennebec potato chips, it would have cost $4 more to substitute fries. END

BEGIN NOW  A friend who knows I like fried chicken said I had to come here and try their buttermilk fried chicken. END
BEGIN NOW    $18 for half a chicken, she said. END
BEGIN NOW    At those prices, it'd better be some chicken, I said. END
BEGIN NOW  In the first place, it isn't half a chicken. END

BEGIN NOW  )  It's two pieces, a boneless breast and a drumstick (not boneless), sort of melded together with a bridge of excess breading. END
BEGIN NOW    When it was served, I was told "the only bone is in the drumstick", which suggested that there might be at least a boneless thigh or a boneless wing in there somewhere, but there wasn't. END
BEGIN NOW  The breading was very crunchy and very thick. END
BEGIN NOW    It had an interesting seasoning, that was its best point. END
BEGIN NOW    It was quite tolerable with the thick, not particularly moist breast meat. END
BEGIN NOW    Once I'd eaten that, though, the breading became overwhelming, and I was glad there wasn't any more. END
BEGIN NOW  After leaving here, I drove up Telegraph and went past a Church's, and I thought: I could have gotten twice as much fried chicken, just as good and with less heavy breading, for half as much money, if I'd gone here instead. END

BEGIN NOW    Auntie charges a 15% surcharge to help pay for the entire staff. END
BEGIN NOW    You may also leave and additional amount that will go directly to your server. END
BEGIN NOW    And like a good Aunt, she has broken down what the extra 3% or 5% for your server would be. END
BEGIN NOW    You read this coming into the restaurant, you read it again at the table and on your tab. END
BEGIN NOW  The cost of doing business is just that. END
BEGIN NOW    Whatever you have to pay to keep your place staffed well should be built into the cost of your meals, not let the patron work on supplementing your payroll. END

BEGIN NOW   The pork tenderloin was the star dish of the night; I would *HIGHLY* recommend ordering it. END
BEGIN NOW   The trout was also pretty good, although probably fishier than the ono would have been. END

BEGIN NOW   The hazelnut cake came warm from the oven and with homemade ice cream: yum! The cheesecake had a very strong goat aftertaste. END

BEGIN NOW  Located in the same building in, or at least next door to, a senior living facility, the Terrace Room offers a gorgeous view of Lake Merritt from the west, which means that most of the time you won't be blinded by the sun like you would from the other side of the lake. END
BEGIN NOW  The food offerings include all the usual dishes you'd expect of a mainstream Californian restaurant, with the dishes sticking more towards the familiar instead of the inventive. END
BEGIN NOW   Moreover, given the generally average quality of the dishes, the prices seem just a bit steep. END
BEGIN NOW  Overall, the atmosphere here is rather quiet and sedate. END
BEGIN NOW   Adding to this is the fact that, lake view aside, the place feels like a country cottage. END
BEGIN NOW   Your best bet would probably be brunch, when you can enjoy a sunny view of the lake, and when other folks dining at the restaurant are also in sunny dispositions. END

BEGIN NOW  Dogwood is a solid bar in a happening stretch of town, right near the Fox Theatre where Telegraph branches off Broadway towards the north. END
BEGIN NOW   There's a good variety of tasty cocktails to choose from, and the bartenders are knowledgeable and and friendly enough to make anything you want. END
BEGIN NOW   What's more, there's a decent menu of munchies, like the totally delicious cubanito sandwich I tried. END
BEGIN NOW   While the interior might feel a bit dark as you walk in, you'll adjust quickly to the cozy yet retro-sleek ambience. END
BEGIN NOW  Also, you have to give the owners credit for sticking it out here over the years. END
BEGIN NOW   Dogwood is located on such a busy street corner that drunk drivers have crashed into it twice, while rioters have also smashed the windows twice. END
BEGIN NOW   Nevertheless, the area is on the way up and  the owners have bounced back each time. END
BEGIN NOW   Judging by the healthy crowds this place gets, it looks like the community has embraced Dogwood as well. END
BEGIN NOW  Came here before a show at the Fox Theater to grab a few drinks. END

BEGIN NOW   The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW    I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW    After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW    Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW    I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW   There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW    With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW    I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW    The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW    Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW    The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW   If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW   The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW    The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW   As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW    Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW     Or if you're not prepared, be friendly and gracious about it - smile maybe?  Most Oaklanders are understanding about shortages of drinks and staff, but not about being treated poorly. END
BEGIN NOW     I'd give this place another chance (based on the doorman alone, actually) to hopefully make some positive changes after a crappy friday night opening. END
BEGIN NOW    They're supposed to also have shows, which I'd go to check out. END
BEGIN NOW    However, there are so many better options that have their stuff together in Oakland, so I'm not in a hurry to go back. END
BEGIN NOW   To illustrate why not, a couple Fridays ago, same group of friends ended up at Van Kleef and the owner was walking around passing out several rounds of complimentary tomatoes with vinegar/sea salt to everyone in the bar. END
BEGIN NOW     And it wasn't a special occasion. END

BEGIN NOW   Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW   From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW   With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW   Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW    It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END

BEGIN NOW    Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW    Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW   And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END

BEGIN NOW   This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW   Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW    The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW    There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW    The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW    The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW    All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW   Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW    The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW    I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW    Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW    I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW    Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW    They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW   The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW    My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW    I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW    A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW   Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW    While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW    While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END

BEGIN NOW    I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW   There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW    With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW    I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW    The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW    Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW    The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW   If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW   The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW    The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW   As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END

BEGIN NOW   Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW   From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW   With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW   Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW    It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END
BEGIN NOW   Works out great for us Oaklanders. END

BEGIN NOW    The decor is kind of stunning, the drinks are solid, the staff is a fantastic group of people. END
BEGIN NOW    Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW    Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW   And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END
BEGIN NOW    But I'd rather be spending my Saturday night with good company and good drinks and good tunes than plop down somewhere where the bartender has nothing to do but sit in front of me and pour my bevvies. END

BEGIN NOW   This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW   Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW    The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW    There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW    The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW    The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW    All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW   Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW    The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW    I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW    Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW    I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW    Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW    They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW   The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW    My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW    I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW    A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW   Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW    While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW    While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW   "Oh, he's very popular Ed. END
BEGIN NOW    The sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, dickheads - they all adore him. END
BEGIN NOW    They think he's a righteous dude. END
BEGIN NOW   "-- from "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"A visit to Heart &amp; Dagger often reminds me of these words. END
BEGIN NOW    As watering holes go, it may not be for every body, but it has a strikingly wide array of fans. END
BEGIN NOW    And for us fans, it holds a piece of our hearts. END
BEGIN NOW    The vibe is casual (read: 'divey'), distinctly Oakland, with a wild undercurrent befitting a David Lynch film. END
BEGIN NOW    A biker bar only 'modestly' gentrified by neo-Oaklandites/wannabees/over-incomed geeks, to which I confess a partial complicity. END
BEGIN NOW     The playground segments into roughly three arenas:  (1) Bar area, where the bees get their honey -- and the barkeeps, both efficient and commanding, do a great job keeping the drones and workers happy. END
BEGIN NOW    Beer specials and shots of liquor are an excellent value, especially during HH, when my lovely Bulliet Manhattans are especially generous. END
BEGIN NOW    (2) Patio, definitely favored by the dog-partnered and smoking clientele, and seems to collect the more regular patrons. END
BEGIN NOW    Gossip is overheard, smiles are witnessed, wafting cigarette smoke is inhaled. END
BEGIN NOW    Water from two giant ThermosTM coolers is free and easily accessed for both two and four-legged visitors back here. END
BEGIN NOW   And then there is (3), the pool table. END
BEGIN NOW     Where I learned, thanks to tutelage from billiards Maestro M and a few tips from other regulars, to now actually almost *not* suck at pool-playing. END
BEGIN NOW     Back to (3) in a bit. END
BEGIN NOW    For the bar en masse though: at its heart of gold though does push the tip of its dagger, as visits here have not always been a feel-good utopian experience. END
BEGIN NOW    I've seen people verbally insulted or kicked out for debatable reasons by the staff (actually mostly just one staff member, whose shifts are minimal); heard obnoxious comments by drunk and/or loud bigots; spied sketchy characters sporting knives in their back pocket, and witnessed a few "lively" disagreements over 8-ball. END
BEGIN NOW    Admittedly, H&amp;D is an onion with many layers, and not all those layers are pretty. END
BEGIN NOW     The trifling edginess is in reality as much an allure as a downer, and a metaphor and microcosm of our world and city and a reminder that good or bad you're still a part of it so why not be a positive part or at the very least learn how to deal with it? In reality, I don't wax all philosophic like that when I visit here. END
BEGIN NOW    Which brings us back to (3):  I do, truly, enjoy the regular pool players, and the competition and camaraderie I'm fortunate to have shared. END
BEGIN NOW     I'm a square peg for several reasons in H&amp;D, but the bonding with other such pegs or non-pegs is the reason I love to visit. END
BEGIN NOW    And on those visits, I get to practice my shot, nurse my bourbon, and inhale the simple sideways joys that life has to offer. END
BEGIN NOW   Can one sum up H&amp;D in a single catchphrase?  "All for one, one for all, just watch your wallet and drink. END
BEGIN NOW   " "You don't have to be a biker to come, but it don't hurt if you are one. END
BEGIN NOW   " "A bar of inimitable substance and a multitude of substances. END
BEGIN NOW   " Nah . END
BEGIN NOW    screw that. END
BEGIN NOW    Heart and Dagger defies an easy Yelp review description. END
BEGIN NOW    And I'm guessing they like it that way. END
BEGIN NOW    Just be chill, be respectful, be unorthodox, be free, and be yourself. END
BEGIN NOW    It's not to be analyzed. END
BEGIN NOW    Just enjoyed. END

BEGIN NOW    The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW     I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW     After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW     Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW     I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW    There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW     With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW     I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW     Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW     The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW    If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW    The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW     The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW    As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW    Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW    From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW    With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW    Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END

BEGIN NOW     Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW     Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW    And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END

BEGIN NOW    This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW    Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW     The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW     There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW     The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW     The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW     All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW    Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW     The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW     I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW     I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW     Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW     They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW    The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW     My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW     A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW    Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW     While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW     While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW     I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW     After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW     Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW     I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW    There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW     With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW     I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW     Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW     The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW    If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW    The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW     The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW    As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW    Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW    From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW    With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW    Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW     It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END

BEGIN NOW      Comfy chairs and spinning bar stools and prices are reasonable. END
BEGIN NOW      Lots of street parking but may have to drive around the block one or two times. END
BEGIN NOW    This is really the only reason I go out after dark. END
BEGIN NOW     Which, granted, still doesn't happen as often as it should - there are regular awesome shows here featuring a bevy of great local garage bands upstairs, and some excellent DJs downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW     The decor is kind of stunning, the drinks are solid, the staff is a fantastic group of people. END
BEGIN NOW     Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW     Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW    And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END
BEGIN NOW     But I'd rather be spending my Saturday night with good company and good drinks and good tunes than plop down somewhere where the bartender has nothing to do but sit in front of me and pour my bevvies. END
BEGIN NOW     If I'm just looking to get drunk quick I'll stay home. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip: regular Monday-night stand-up downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip 2: AC Transit late-night free shuttle b/t downtown &amp; JLS. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip 3: Nations next door is open until 1, but no late-night breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW    The hubs and I stopped in for an after dinner drink. END
BEGIN NOW     I've did some research on yelp about this place and thought that this bar had a pretty cool vibe based on the interior pictures. END
BEGIN NOW     The decor is pretty neat with a speak easy feel. END
BEGIN NOW     Old leather wingbacked chairs and dark ornate wallpaper and wood paneling gives you the feeling that this is the type of place to enjoy a good stiff drink. END
BEGIN NOW     As much as it looked old-fashioned inside, it's really eclectic in that they have live music and a DJ table. END

BEGIN NOW    This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW    Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW     The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW     There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW     The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW     The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW     All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW    Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW     The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW     I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW     I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW     Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW     They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW    The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW     My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW     A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW    Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW     While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW     While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    "Oh, he's very popular Ed. END
BEGIN NOW     The sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, dickheads - they all adore him. END
BEGIN NOW     They think he's a righteous dude. END
BEGIN NOW    "-- from "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"A visit to Heart &amp; Dagger often reminds me of these words. END
BEGIN NOW     As watering holes go, it may not be for every body, but it has a strikingly wide array of fans. END
BEGIN NOW     And for us fans, it holds a piece of our hearts. END
BEGIN NOW     The vibe is casual (read: 'divey'), distinctly Oakland, with a wild undercurrent befitting a David Lynch film. END
BEGIN NOW     A biker bar only 'modestly' gentrified by neo-Oaklandites/wannabees/over-incomed geeks, to which I confess a partial complicity. END
BEGIN NOW      The playground segments into roughly three arenas:  (1) Bar area, where the bees get their honey -- and the barkeeps, both efficient and commanding, do a great job keeping the drones and workers happy. END
BEGIN NOW     Beer specials and shots of liquor are an excellent value, especially during HH, when my lovely Bulliet Manhattans are especially generous. END
BEGIN NOW     (2) Patio, definitely favored by the dog-partnered and smoking clientele, and seems to collect the more regular patrons. END
BEGIN NOW     Gossip is overheard, smiles are witnessed, wafting cigarette smoke is inhaled. END
BEGIN NOW     Water from two giant ThermosTM coolers is free and easily accessed for both two and four-legged visitors back here. END
BEGIN NOW    And then there is (3), the pool table. END
BEGIN NOW      Where I learned, thanks to tutelage from billiards Maestro M and a few tips from other regulars, to now actually almost *not* suck at pool-playing. END
BEGIN NOW      Back to (3) in a bit. END
BEGIN NOW     For the bar en masse though: at its heart of gold though does push the tip of its dagger, as visits here have not always been a feel-good utopian experience. END
BEGIN NOW     I've seen people verbally insulted or kicked out for debatable reasons by the staff (actually mostly just one staff member, whose shifts are minimal); heard obnoxious comments by drunk and/or loud bigots; spied sketchy characters sporting knives in their back pocket, and witnessed a few "lively" disagreements over 8-ball. END
BEGIN NOW     Admittedly, H&amp;D is an onion with many layers, and not all those layers are pretty. END
BEGIN NOW      The trifling edginess is in reality as much an allure as a downer, and a metaphor and microcosm of our world and city and a reminder that good or bad you're still a part of it so why not be a positive part or at the very least learn how to deal with it? In reality, I don't wax all philosophic like that when I visit here. END
BEGIN NOW     Which brings us back to (3):  I do, truly, enjoy the regular pool players, and the competition and camaraderie I'm fortunate to have shared. END
BEGIN NOW      I'm a square peg for several reasons in H&amp;D, but the bonding with other such pegs or non-pegs is the reason I love to visit. END
BEGIN NOW     And on those visits, I get to practice my shot, nurse my bourbon, and inhale the simple sideways joys that life has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    Cosecha is a Mexican eatery with a nouvelle California twist. END
BEGIN NOW     It's located inside old Oakland's Swan's Market. END
BEGIN NOW     Solid wooden benches-- amenable to communal style seating -- are set up in front of their ordering counter. END
BEGIN NOW     I actually love shared dining like this; seems only fitting for a 'market' context. END
BEGIN NOW    The open wall aspect of this market is attractive; chose to avoid the interior ceiling fans and be warmed by the direct sun. END
BEGIN NOW     People sitting outside were accompanied by their pets. END
BEGIN NOW     The ordering line took just a bit of time. END
BEGIN NOW     I loved observing the hustle and bustle of the open prep station behind the glass. END
BEGIN NOW      While waiting in line, I perused the paper menu pasted onto the glass counter. END
BEGIN NOW      I was there towards the end of weekend brunch (they close at 3:00 p. END
BEGIN NOW    m. END
BEGIN NOW    ) I ordered the wild shrimp tacos and the horchata latte, following the tip from Bon Appetit's August 2015 issue which featured Oakland dining spots including Cosecha. END
BEGIN NOW      Place your order at the counter and pay, then servers bring your food out. END
BEGIN NOW      The horchata latte was sheer cinnamon-y goodness served in a tall glass-- light, sweet, and tinged with coffee tones. END
BEGIN NOW      I thought it would be the perfect non-dairy counterpoint to spicy Mexican chillies. END
BEGIN NOW      The two corn tortillas piled high with batter-fried shrimp were nicely presented. END
BEGIN NOW     The shrimp sat on shredded cabbage, were topped with a chili-infused crema sauce and garnished with jalapeno and cilantro. END
BEGIN NOW     The tacos weren't spicy and the cup of beans on the side were well-flavored. END
BEGIN NOW     The shrimp were high quality and fresh with a firm bite (none of the mealy texture of aquaculture-produced shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW    ) My only gripe might be the quantity size--too small. END
BEGIN NOW      The prices will reveal that this is not another street-stall taco shop although it functions like one. END
BEGIN NOW     I paid around $15 for the gourmet, delicately flavored shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW      This place offers sufficiently unique taste that it's worth a special treat, but it wouldn't be my daily go-to, based on price alone. END
BEGIN NOW      There are plenty of more ordinary tacquerias for everyday dining. END
