BEGIN NOW    The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW     I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW     After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW     Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW     I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW    There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW     With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW     I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW     Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW     The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW    If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW    The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW     The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW    As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW    Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW    From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW    With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW    Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW     It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END

BEGIN NOW     Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW     Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW    And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END

BEGIN NOW    This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW    Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW     The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW     There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW     The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW     The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW     All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW    Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW     The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW     I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW     I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW     Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW     They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW    The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW     My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW     A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW    Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW     While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW     While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW     I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW     After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW     Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW     I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW    There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW     With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW     I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW     Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW     The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW    If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW    The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW     The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW    As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW     Then there's the flocked wallpaper, exposed old-timey lighting, and the portraits of nudes languorously hanging from the walls. END
BEGIN NOW     What makes this place awesome is definitely the decor, but there's also a nice variety of liquors and friendly service. END
BEGIN NOW     I'd recommend stopping by on a Sunday when it's not too packed to get a seat. END
BEGIN NOW    Fantastic cocktails. END
BEGIN NOW    Friendly and knowledgeable staff. END

BEGIN NOW    Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW    From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW    With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW    Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW     It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END
BEGIN NOW    Works out great for us Oaklanders. END

BEGIN NOW    This is really the only reason I go out after dark. END
BEGIN NOW     Which, granted, still doesn't happen as often as it should - there are regular awesome shows here featuring a bevy of great local garage bands upstairs, and some excellent DJs downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW     The decor is kind of stunning, the drinks are solid, the staff is a fantastic group of people. END
BEGIN NOW     Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW     Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW    And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END
BEGIN NOW     But I'd rather be spending my Saturday night with good company and good drinks and good tunes than plop down somewhere where the bartender has nothing to do but sit in front of me and pour my bevvies. END
BEGIN NOW     If I'm just looking to get drunk quick I'll stay home. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip: regular Monday-night stand-up downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip 2: AC Transit late-night free shuttle b/t downtown &amp; JLS. END
BEGIN NOW    Pro-tip 3: Nations next door is open until 1, but no late-night breakfast. END

BEGIN NOW    This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW    Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW     The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW     There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW     The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW     The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW     All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW    Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW     The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW     I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW     I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW     Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW     They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW    The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW     My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW     I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW     A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW    Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW     While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW     While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW    "Oh, he's very popular Ed. END
BEGIN NOW     The sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, dickheads - they all adore him. END
BEGIN NOW     They think he's a righteous dude. END
BEGIN NOW    "-- from "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"A visit to Heart &amp; Dagger often reminds me of these words. END
BEGIN NOW     As watering holes go, it may not be for every body, but it has a strikingly wide array of fans. END
BEGIN NOW     And for us fans, it holds a piece of our hearts. END
BEGIN NOW     The vibe is casual (read: 'divey'), distinctly Oakland, with a wild undercurrent befitting a David Lynch film. END
BEGIN NOW     A biker bar only 'modestly' gentrified by neo-Oaklandites/wannabees/over-incomed geeks, to which I confess a partial complicity. END
BEGIN NOW      The playground segments into roughly three arenas:  (1) Bar area, where the bees get their honey -- and the barkeeps, both efficient and commanding, do a great job keeping the drones and workers happy. END
BEGIN NOW     Beer specials and shots of liquor are an excellent value, especially during HH, when my lovely Bulliet Manhattans are especially generous. END
BEGIN NOW     (2) Patio, definitely favored by the dog-partnered and smoking clientele, and seems to collect the more regular patrons. END
BEGIN NOW     Gossip is overheard, smiles are witnessed, wafting cigarette smoke is inhaled. END
BEGIN NOW     Water from two giant ThermosTM coolers is free and easily accessed for both two and four-legged visitors back here. END
BEGIN NOW    And then there is (3), the pool table. END
BEGIN NOW      Where I learned, thanks to tutelage from billiards Maestro M and a few tips from other regulars, to now actually almost *not* suck at pool-playing. END
BEGIN NOW      Back to (3) in a bit. END
BEGIN NOW     For the bar en masse though: at its heart of gold though does push the tip of its dagger, as visits here have not always been a feel-good utopian experience. END
BEGIN NOW     I've seen people verbally insulted or kicked out for debatable reasons by the staff (actually mostly just one staff member, whose shifts are minimal); heard obnoxious comments by drunk and/or loud bigots; spied sketchy characters sporting knives in their back pocket, and witnessed a few "lively" disagreements over 8-ball. END
BEGIN NOW     Admittedly, H&amp;D is an onion with many layers, and not all those layers are pretty. END
BEGIN NOW      The trifling edginess is in reality as much an allure as a downer, and a metaphor and microcosm of our world and city and a reminder that good or bad you're still a part of it so why not be a positive part or at the very least learn how to deal with it? In reality, I don't wax all philosophic like that when I visit here. END
BEGIN NOW     Which brings us back to (3):  I do, truly, enjoy the regular pool players, and the competition and camaraderie I'm fortunate to have shared. END
BEGIN NOW      I'm a square peg for several reasons in H&amp;D, but the bonding with other such pegs or non-pegs is the reason I love to visit. END
BEGIN NOW     And on those visits, I get to practice my shot, nurse my bourbon, and inhale the simple sideways joys that life has to offer. END
BEGIN NOW    Can one sum up H&amp;D in a single catchphrase?  "All for one, one for all, just watch your wallet and drink. END
BEGIN NOW    " "You don't have to be a biker to come, but it don't hurt if you are one. END
BEGIN NOW    " "A bar of inimitable substance and a multitude of substances. END
BEGIN NOW    " Nah . END
BEGIN NOW     screw that. END
BEGIN NOW     Heart and Dagger defies an easy Yelp review description. END
BEGIN NOW     And I'm guessing they like it that way. END
BEGIN NOW     Just be chill, be respectful, be unorthodox, be free, and be yourself. END
BEGIN NOW     It's not to be analyzed. END
BEGIN NOW     Just enjoyed. END
BEGIN NOW    If you like dive bars without the meth mouth, Sons of Anarchy watching patrons, Heart and Dagger will sit very well with you. END

BEGIN NOW    Cosecha is a Mexican eatery with a nouvelle California twist. END
BEGIN NOW     It's located inside old Oakland's Swan's Market. END
BEGIN NOW     Solid wooden benches-- amenable to communal style seating -- are set up in front of their ordering counter. END
BEGIN NOW     I actually love shared dining like this; seems only fitting for a 'market' context. END
BEGIN NOW    The open wall aspect of this market is attractive; chose to avoid the interior ceiling fans and be warmed by the direct sun. END
BEGIN NOW     People sitting outside were accompanied by their pets. END
BEGIN NOW     The ordering line took just a bit of time. END
BEGIN NOW     I loved observing the hustle and bustle of the open prep station behind the glass. END
BEGIN NOW      While waiting in line, I perused the paper menu pasted onto the glass counter. END
BEGIN NOW      I was there towards the end of weekend brunch (they close at 3:00 p. END
BEGIN NOW    m. END
BEGIN NOW    ) I ordered the wild shrimp tacos and the horchata latte, following the tip from Bon Appetit's August 2015 issue which featured Oakland dining spots including Cosecha. END
BEGIN NOW      Place your order at the counter and pay, then servers bring your food out. END
BEGIN NOW      The horchata latte was sheer cinnamon-y goodness served in a tall glass-- light, sweet, and tinged with coffee tones. END
BEGIN NOW      I thought it would be the perfect non-dairy counterpoint to spicy Mexican chillies. END
BEGIN NOW      The two corn tortillas piled high with batter-fried shrimp were nicely presented. END
BEGIN NOW     The shrimp sat on shredded cabbage, were topped with a chili-infused crema sauce and garnished with jalapeno and cilantro. END
BEGIN NOW     The tacos weren't spicy and the cup of beans on the side were well-flavored. END
BEGIN NOW     The shrimp were high quality and fresh with a firm bite (none of the mealy texture of aquaculture-produced shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW    ) My only gripe might be the quantity size--too small. END
BEGIN NOW      The prices will reveal that this is not another street-stall taco shop although it functions like one. END
BEGIN NOW     I paid around $15 for the gourmet, delicately flavored shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW      This place offers sufficiently unique taste that it's worth a special treat, but it wouldn't be my daily go-to, based on price alone. END
BEGIN NOW      There are plenty of more ordinary tacquerias for everyday dining. END

BEGIN NOW    Fun place in Oakland! I came here for dinner with friends after a day of drinking our way through Napa. END

BEGIN NOW     Fun service, chill atmosphere. END
BEGIN NOW    Lively, quality gastropub that's helping to put the area around 40th Street and Broadway on the map as a new dining corridor in Oakland, with a feel and identity that's distinct from gentrified Piedmont Avenue not far away. END
BEGIN NOW    The first things you notice are the tremendous craft beer selection and the meat/pork-heavy menu. END
BEGIN NOW     As for the beer, the selection is quite extensive and although it features mostly craft brews, it looks like it's been curated to be very comprehensive across all major styles. END
BEGIN NOW     Moreover, if you have any questions about any single beer item, you could ask for a little taste, or you could ask for advice on what pairs well with certain dishes on the menu. END
BEGIN NOW    And as for the menu, it is quite meat-heavy (although I assume some items may be vegetarian-friendly or can be made so). END
BEGIN NOW     While items like sausages might sound steep at around $13, the portion size is tremendous, and the case of the "Got Seoul" sausage that they offered recently, it comes topped uniquely with Asian ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     There are even meatier, more substantial entrees available too, all with whimsical names to them. END
BEGIN NOW     Everything is so meaty and delicious, you'll be "mmm"-ing with approval throughout the meal. END
BEGIN NOW    The overall atmosphere is quite friendly and festive, with lots of communal seating, and the place can be packed most of the time. END
BEGIN NOW     Service is also knowledgeable and friendly too. END
BEGIN NOW     Chalk up another win for the 40th Street area and for the Oakland dining scene. END

BEGIN NOW    My girlfriend and I went on a double date with two of our friends, and we had dinner at The Hog's Apothecary. END
BEGIN NOW     It was a Saturday night, and there was a good crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     This restaurant has communal tables which is something that I absolutely disdain. END
BEGIN NOW     As someone who has a busy schedule and is in a long distance relationship, my time with my girlfriend, my friends, and my family is precious to me. END
BEGIN NOW     When I finally get the time to spend with my self-selected company, I hate having to shout over strangers to avoid being drowned out by their own conversations. END
BEGIN NOW     That being said, the communal tables at Hog's were not nearly as cramped as the ones at Homeroom. END
BEGIN NOW     You still have to do a lot of yelling though. END
BEGIN NOW     The hard wooden benches were pretty uncomfortable too. END
BEGIN NOW     Everything else about the restaurant was really great though. END
BEGIN NOW     They offer a preponderance of great local and semi-local beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW     I had the Buddha's Hand IPA from Berryessa Brewing in Winters, CA, and it was awesome. END
BEGIN NOW     It was not overly bitter and had a pleasant citrus taste from the Buddha's hand. END
BEGIN NOW     Everyone else enjoyed their beers as well. END
BEGIN NOW    My girlfriend and I started our meal with a soft pretzel. END
BEGIN NOW     The pretzel had a rich, brown skin and was light and airy on the inside. END

BEGIN NOW     The heat from the mustard hits you right in the sinuses (in a good way). END
BEGIN NOW    For our meal, we shared the corn dog and the Jamaican Me Crazy sausage. END
BEGIN NOW    Corn dog: Easily one of the best (non-State Fair) corn dogs I've ever had. END
BEGIN NOW     However, I feel like corn dogs are kind of like donuts. END
BEGIN NOW     Awful ones are still pretty good, and even the best version with the best possible ingredients is only a few times better than the average ones. END
BEGIN NOW     Jamaican Me Crazy: The sausage was tasty, although the jerk seasoning could have been a little more bold. END
BEGIN NOW     I only tasted faint traces of allspice. END
BEGIN NOW     The bun pillow-soft and provided a textural contrast to the pop I would get when biting into the casing of the sausage. END
BEGIN NOW     The potato chips were tasty too. END

BEGIN NOW    With a menu that is constantly changing, Hog's Apothecary has a lot to offer, even if the day's menu isn't super extensive - roughly a dozen starters and sides, a handful of sausages, and a few different entrées. END
BEGIN NOW      What's more, there's beer and lots of it. END

BEGIN NOW    -- SPICY PORK CRACKLIN'S. END
BEGIN NOW    $3(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW    com/biz_photos/the-…)These cracklin's are crackin'!  Not only are they borderline addictive, but they really do pack some heat, as every piece is coated with a spicy, mouth-watering seasoning (don't forget the lime!). END
BEGIN NOW      What's more, the portion is quite generous!  A great starter for groups to share. END

BEGIN NOW    $6(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW    com/biz_photos/the-…)Although larger slices of bread would have been nice to spread out all that pate, I'm not definitely not complaining about those giant gobs either!  While every bite was rich and decadent, the taste was also nicely accentuated by the sea salt and the berries. END
BEGIN NOW      If this isn't the best one I've had, it wouldn't be far behind. END
BEGIN NOW    -- SUPERFECTA SAUSAGE SANDWICH - Pork, Rabbit, Chicken, Tim's Brown Ale, Basque Chili &amp; Mild Herbs, Fennel-Onion Braise, Dijon Mustard. END

BEGIN NOW      Great food otherwise, an awesome selection of beers, fantastic staff (they let our large party split our bill into smaller tabs), and (relatively) easy parking. END

BEGIN NOW    Brad and John have taken what once was a dilapidated laundromat with a seedy past and created a neighborhood gathering spot that is open, airy and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW      I was at first slightly put off by the long tables and benches, as I generally prefer not to share my table with people I don't know, but I came to realize that it promotes conversation between strangers and contributes to the neighborhood feel. END
BEGIN NOW      While the dining area is not huge, the high ceiling with exposed beams and open air skylight make it feel much larger. END
BEGIN NOW      "Hog's" boasts more taps than I could get through in a week. END
BEGIN NOW      They have beers on tap to appeal to any beer drinker. END
BEGIN NOW      They also cycle beers in and out to keep the selections new and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW      Now. END
BEGIN NOW     on to the food itself. END
BEGIN NOW      We started out with the warm pretzel for two with cheese sauce and mustard. END
BEGIN NOW     ( One thing you must know before I go further. END
BEGIN NOW      Nearly everything you eat is made in house. END
BEGIN NOW      The mustard, the cheese, the sausage, the kraut. END
BEGIN NOW      the exceptions being the buns and, if memory serves, the pretzel itself. END
BEGIN NOW     )  The pretzel was hot and delicious. END
BEGIN NOW      The house made mustard and cheese sauce were the perfect compliment. END
BEGIN NOW      There's just no comparison between jar mustard and mustard made fresh that day. END
BEGIN NOW      For my entree I ordered the schnitzel. END
BEGIN NOW      It's really easy to overcook pork and make it dry. END
BEGIN NOW      Not the case here. END
BEGIN NOW      The breading was light, the pork juicy and while I used my knife at first, I ended up using just my fork as it was so tender. END
BEGIN NOW      The arugula and warm potato salad only served to enhance the succulent pork. END
BEGIN NOW      My dining companions ordered the 'Basa' with kraut and the Devil Bird fried chicken. END
BEGIN NOW      I was raised by a German mother who made ( and at 70 still makes ) her own kraut. END
BEGIN NOW     As much as I cannot believe I am saying this, ( Sorry, Mom ) the kraut at Hog's is better. END
BEGIN NOW      especially thrown on top of a juicy and savory sausage with just the right pop from the casing. END
BEGIN NOW      ( Sorry, Mom ) The chicken was juicy and full of flavor, but it's the breading that really takes it over the top. END
BEGIN NOW      It's hard to describe, but there's a slight sweetness to it that, to me, was reminiscent of that first bite of a churro or a Krispy Kreme that immediately makes you want another bite. END
BEGIN NOW      It's difficult NOT to want to clean your plate. END
BEGIN NOW    I do have one regret. END
BEGIN NOW      Only one. END
BEGIN NOW      I didn't try dessert. END
BEGIN NOW      We all surveyed the dessert menu, but after a great beer and amazing food there was just no room. END
BEGIN NOW    I know I am a friend and friends tend to be biased so I encourage you to read other reviews. END
BEGIN NOW      Aside from the small contingent of nay-sayers you will find that the overall rating of 4/5 stars is well earned and well deserved. END
BEGIN NOW      It's worth checking out. END

BEGIN NOW      However, when you walk inside, you are greeted by a hostess and added to the list for a seat at one of their community tables or bar stools along the window counters. END

BEGIN NOW    Lively, quality gastropub that's helping to put the area around 40th Street and Broadway on the map as a new dining corridor in Oakland, with a feel and identity that's distinct from gentrified Piedmont Avenue not far away. END
BEGIN NOW    The first things you notice are the tremendous craft beer selection and the meat/pork-heavy menu. END
BEGIN NOW     As for the beer, the selection is quite extensive and although it features mostly craft brews, it looks like it's been curated to be very comprehensive across all major styles. END
BEGIN NOW     Moreover, if you have any questions about any single beer item, you could ask for a little taste, or you could ask for advice on what pairs well with certain dishes on the menu. END
BEGIN NOW    And as for the menu, it is quite meat-heavy (although I assume some items may be vegetarian-friendly or can be made so). END
BEGIN NOW     While items like sausages might sound steep at around $13, the portion size is tremendous, and the case of the "Got Seoul" sausage that they offered recently, it comes topped uniquely with Asian ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW     There are even meatier, more substantial entrees available too, all with whimsical names to them. END
BEGIN NOW     Everything is so meaty and delicious, you'll be "mmm"-ing with approval throughout the meal. END
BEGIN NOW    The overall atmosphere is quite friendly and festive, with lots of communal seating, and the place can be packed most of the time. END
BEGIN NOW     Service is also knowledgeable and friendly too. END
BEGIN NOW     Chalk up another win for the 40th Street area and for the Oakland dining scene. END

BEGIN NOW    My girlfriend and I went on a double date with two of our friends, and we had dinner at The Hog's Apothecary. END
BEGIN NOW     It was a Saturday night, and there was a good crowd. END
BEGIN NOW     This restaurant has communal tables which is something that I absolutely disdain. END
BEGIN NOW     As someone who has a busy schedule and is in a long distance relationship, my time with my girlfriend, my friends, and my family is precious to me. END
BEGIN NOW     When I finally get the time to spend with my self-selected company, I hate having to shout over strangers to avoid being drowned out by their own conversations. END
BEGIN NOW     That being said, the communal tables at Hog's were not nearly as cramped as the ones at Homeroom. END
BEGIN NOW     You still have to do a lot of yelling though. END
BEGIN NOW     The hard wooden benches were pretty uncomfortable too. END
BEGIN NOW     Everything else about the restaurant was really great though. END
BEGIN NOW     They offer a preponderance of great local and semi-local beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW     I had the Buddha's Hand IPA from Berryessa Brewing in Winters, CA, and it was awesome. END
BEGIN NOW     It was not overly bitter and had a pleasant citrus taste from the Buddha's hand. END
BEGIN NOW     Everyone else enjoyed their beers as well. END
BEGIN NOW    My girlfriend and I started our meal with a soft pretzel. END
BEGIN NOW     The pretzel had a rich, brown skin and was light and airy on the inside. END
BEGIN NOW     I really enjoyed the spicy mustard dipping sauce that came with the pretzel. END
BEGIN NOW     The heat from the mustard hits you right in the sinuses (in a good way). END
BEGIN NOW    For our meal, we shared the corn dog and the Jamaican Me Crazy sausage. END
BEGIN NOW    Corn dog: Easily one of the best (non-State Fair) corn dogs I've ever had. END
BEGIN NOW     However, I feel like corn dogs are kind of like donuts. END
BEGIN NOW     Awful ones are still pretty good, and even the best version with the best possible ingredients is only a few times better than the average ones. END
BEGIN NOW     Jamaican Me Crazy: The sausage was tasty, although the jerk seasoning could have been a little more bold. END
BEGIN NOW     I only tasted faint traces of allspice. END
BEGIN NOW     The bun pillow-soft and provided a textural contrast to the pop I would get when biting into the casing of the sausage. END
BEGIN NOW     The potato chips were tasty too. END
BEGIN NOW     While both items were really good, they do seem a little overpriced for what they are. END
BEGIN NOW    Our service was good, although there was some redundancy between the servers. END
BEGIN NOW     Several different people came around to take our orders and this led to some confusion when my girlfriend ordered a second beer and two of the servers mistakenly thought that the other one would get the beer. END
BEGIN NOW     They got it right eventually though. END
BEGIN NOW    Overall, I like The Hog's Apothecary and would come back another time for beer and a corn dog. END

BEGIN NOW      They use boneless chicken thighs, so you can forgo utensils and just dig in with your bare hands!My wife ordered a benedict, which comes with the house pastrami. END
BEGIN NOW      The egg was cooked perfectly, but the dish (along with the house potatoes) were a little on the salty side. END

BEGIN NOW      After all, between Hog's Apothecary's name and their giant pig statue that hovered behind me, it'd practically be sacrilegious not to!  And I am not one to mess with the pork/bacon/pork belly powers that may be (all hail, Bacon!). END
BEGIN NOW    With a menu that is constantly changing, Hog's Apothecary has a lot to offer, even if the day's menu isn't super extensive - roughly a dozen starters and sides, a handful of sausages, and a few different entrées. END
BEGIN NOW      What's more, there's beer and lots of it. END
BEGIN NOW      With over 25 varieties on tap (mostly craft brews), you could even forgo eating and just sample beers all night long. END
BEGIN NOW    -- SPICY PORK CRACKLIN'S. END
BEGIN NOW    $3(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW    com/biz_photos/the-…)These cracklin's are crackin'!  Not only are they borderline addictive, but they really do pack some heat, as every piece is coated with a spicy, mouth-watering seasoning (don't forget the lime!). END
BEGIN NOW      What's more, the portion is quite generous!  A great starter for groups to share. END
BEGIN NOW    -- BOURBON-CHICKEN LIVER PATE. END
BEGIN NOW    $6(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW    com/biz_photos/the-…)Although larger slices of bread would have been nice to spread out all that pate, I'm not definitely not complaining about those giant gobs either!  While every bite was rich and decadent, the taste was also nicely accentuated by the sea salt and the berries. END
BEGIN NOW      If this isn't the best one I've had, it wouldn't be far behind. END
BEGIN NOW    -- SUPERFECTA SAUSAGE SANDWICH - Pork, Rabbit, Chicken, Tim's Brown Ale, Basque Chili &amp; Mild Herbs, Fennel-Onion Braise, Dijon Mustard. END
BEGIN NOW    $14(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW    com/biz_photos/the-…)The only blemish, but it was a big one. END
BEGIN NOW      I was hopeful for trio of meats in the sausage, but it wasn't even juicy, let alone flavorful. END
BEGIN NOW      Ironically, the braise had the opposite effect, overpowering whatever flavor the meat had with fennel. END
BEGIN NOW      Sadly, besides the chips, the only other thing I enjoyed were the pickled vegetables. END
BEGIN NOW    As underwhelming as my order was, it really was the only "bad" thing about my experience. END
BEGIN NOW      Great food otherwise, an awesome selection of beers, fantastic staff (they let our large party split our bill into smaller tabs), and (relatively) easy parking. END
BEGIN NOW      Plus, with several long tables, Hog's Apothecary is grew for groups large or small. END
BEGIN NOW    Also, it's worth noting that the rest of my friends seemed to enjoy their food quite a bit (we all ordered different things), so it wouldn't surprise me if what I had just wasn't one of their better dishes. END
BEGIN NOW      Especially since the starters were really good. END
BEGIN NOW      Rounding up from THREE AND A HALF STARS, but I wonder what might have been if I had only ordered the fried chicken!. END

BEGIN NOW    Thank goodness I don't have to keep the negatives to myself. END
BEGIN NOW      as I couldn't find any. END
BEGIN NOW      In fact, to say I was impressed would be an understatement. END
BEGIN NOW    Brad and John have taken what once was a dilapidated laundromat with a seedy past and created a neighborhood gathering spot that is open, airy and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW      I was at first slightly put off by the long tables and benches, as I generally prefer not to share my table with people I don't know, but I came to realize that it promotes conversation between strangers and contributes to the neighborhood feel. END
BEGIN NOW      While the dining area is not huge, the high ceiling with exposed beams and open air skylight make it feel much larger. END
BEGIN NOW      "Hog's" boasts more taps than I could get through in a week. END
BEGIN NOW      They have beers on tap to appeal to any beer drinker. END
BEGIN NOW      They also cycle beers in and out to keep the selections new and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW      Now. END
BEGIN NOW     on to the food itself. END
BEGIN NOW      We started out with the warm pretzel for two with cheese sauce and mustard. END
BEGIN NOW     ( One thing you must know before I go further. END
BEGIN NOW      Nearly everything you eat is made in house. END
BEGIN NOW      The mustard, the cheese, the sausage, the kraut. END
BEGIN NOW      the exceptions being the buns and, if memory serves, the pretzel itself. END
BEGIN NOW     )  The pretzel was hot and delicious. END
BEGIN NOW      The house made mustard and cheese sauce were the perfect compliment. END
BEGIN NOW      There's just no comparison between jar mustard and mustard made fresh that day. END
BEGIN NOW      For my entree I ordered the schnitzel. END
BEGIN NOW      It's really easy to overcook pork and make it dry. END
BEGIN NOW      Not the case here. END
BEGIN NOW      The breading was light, the pork juicy and while I used my knife at first, I ended up using just my fork as it was so tender. END
BEGIN NOW      The arugula and warm potato salad only served to enhance the succulent pork. END
BEGIN NOW      My dining companions ordered the 'Basa' with kraut and the Devil Bird fried chicken. END
BEGIN NOW      I was raised by a German mother who made ( and at 70 still makes ) her own kraut. END
BEGIN NOW     As much as I cannot believe I am saying this, ( Sorry, Mom ) the kraut at Hog's is better. END
BEGIN NOW      especially thrown on top of a juicy and savory sausage with just the right pop from the casing. END
BEGIN NOW      ( Sorry, Mom ) The chicken was juicy and full of flavor, but it's the breading that really takes it over the top. END
BEGIN NOW      It's hard to describe, but there's a slight sweetness to it that, to me, was reminiscent of that first bite of a churro or a Krispy Kreme that immediately makes you want another bite. END
BEGIN NOW      It's difficult NOT to want to clean your plate. END
BEGIN NOW    I do have one regret. END
BEGIN NOW      Only one. END
BEGIN NOW      I didn't try dessert. END
BEGIN NOW      We all surveyed the dessert menu, but after a great beer and amazing food there was just no room. END
BEGIN NOW    I know I am a friend and friends tend to be biased so I encourage you to read other reviews. END
BEGIN NOW      Aside from the small contingent of nay-sayers you will find that the overall rating of 4/5 stars is well earned and well deserved. END

BEGIN NOW     The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW      I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW      After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW      Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW      I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW     There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW      With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW      I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW      The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW      Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW      The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW     If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW     The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW      The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW     As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW      Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW     Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW     From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW     With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW     Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW      It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END

BEGIN NOW       Lots of street parking but may have to drive around the block one or two times. END
BEGIN NOW     This is really the only reason I go out after dark. END
BEGIN NOW      Which, granted, still doesn't happen as often as it should - there are regular awesome shows here featuring a bevy of great local garage bands upstairs, and some excellent DJs downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW      The decor is kind of stunning, the drinks are solid, the staff is a fantastic group of people. END
BEGIN NOW      Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW      Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW     And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END
BEGIN NOW      But I'd rather be spending my Saturday night with good company and good drinks and good tunes than plop down somewhere where the bartender has nothing to do but sit in front of me and pour my bevvies. END
BEGIN NOW      If I'm just looking to get drunk quick I'll stay home. END
BEGIN NOW     Pro-tip: regular Monday-night stand-up downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW     Pro-tip 2: AC Transit late-night free shuttle b/t downtown &amp; JLS. END
BEGIN NOW     Pro-tip 3: Nations next door is open until 1, but no late-night breakfast. END
BEGIN NOW     The hubs and I stopped in for an after dinner drink. END
BEGIN NOW      I've did some research on yelp about this place and thought that this bar had a pretty cool vibe based on the interior pictures. END
BEGIN NOW      The decor is pretty neat with a speak easy feel. END
BEGIN NOW      Old leather wingbacked chairs and dark ornate wallpaper and wood paneling gives you the feeling that this is the type of place to enjoy a good stiff drink. END
BEGIN NOW      As much as it looked old-fashioned inside, it's really eclectic in that they have live music and a DJ table. END
BEGIN NOW      This probably is a great venue for bands to play because there's a lot of room. END
BEGIN NOW      We went early on a Friday evening so I'm sure this place probably gets really busy later on, but it was kind of weird thinking that the speakeasy ambiance of this joint would soon be filled with hip/hop or rock music. END
BEGIN NOW     but that may be part of it's eclectic charm. END
BEGIN NOW      I would imagine that this place wouldn't be a great place to have a convo with a group of friends late at night due to the music they play, but probably for a happy hour style outing, this would be a good spot to sit and have a few cocktails. END
BEGIN NOW      Although we really liked the ambiance of this place, the cocktails were ok. END
BEGIN NOW      Their list of house cocktails looked really great and the couple that we ordered were good, but compared to some other bars that we frequent, they didn't blow us away. END
BEGIN NOW      Overall, It's a nice looking bar that's probably great for seeing a band or listening/dancing to music while having some drinks. END

BEGIN NOW     This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW     Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW      The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW      There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW      The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW      The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW      All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW     Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW      The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW      I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW      Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW      I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW      Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW      They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW     The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW      My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW      I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW      A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW     Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW      While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW      While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW     The Night Light was quite the surprise discovery. END
BEGIN NOW      I met up with some friends for a birthday celebration on Friday night that kicked off at Plank in Jack London Square. END
BEGIN NOW      After finishing up a game of bowling, we were in need of a new bar for the rest of the evening. END
BEGIN NOW      Luckily one of my friends knew about about The Night Light, so we made the short walk over. END
BEGIN NOW      I was expecting a mediocre dive spot when we first entered, but my first impressions were corrected in short order. END
BEGIN NOW     There is apparently an upstairs area that is used for concerts but we stayed in downstairs area. END
BEGIN NOW      With regard to the downstairs portion of the place, there is a bar with stools that runs the length of the place, some more comfy seats along the opposite wall, and a DJ booth and small dance floor at the far end. END
BEGIN NOW      I thought I was going to bumping into people all night long, but to my pleasant surprise, everyone was extremely chill and there was plenty of space on the dancefloor despite a healthy crowd. END
BEGIN NOW      The DJ played a great mix of hip hop throughout the night. END
BEGIN NOW      Ignoring an initial failed attempt at making an Old Fashioned, the rest of the cocktails for the evening were well-made and tasty. END
BEGIN NOW      The drinks were also reasonably priced (3 for $24 before tip). END
BEGIN NOW     If in the Jack London Square area and looking for a good place to dance and grab a drink, definitely checkout The Night Light. END
BEGIN NOW     The Night Light might look divey from the outside, but the downstairs portion is great for large groups, has a lively, fun vibe on weekend nights, and offers decently priced drinks that pack quite a punch. END
BEGIN NOW      The upstairs portion often hosts live acts for a modest cover. END
BEGIN NOW     As with many Oakland establishments, it's the clientele that really makes things, and, true to Oakland's reputation, the crowds here are diverse and friendly. END
BEGIN NOW      Worth a visit either for chilling out downstairs or checking out a live act upstairs. END

BEGIN NOW       Even though cocktails are on the menu and the other bartender was making them. END

BEGIN NOW       There seemed to be only two main bartenders, and one third who was partially making drinks and partially running around. END

BEGIN NOW       Or if you're not prepared, be friendly and gracious about it - smile maybe?  Most Oaklanders are understanding about shortages of drinks and staff, but not about being treated poorly. END
BEGIN NOW       I'd give this place another chance (based on the doorman alone, actually) to hopefully make some positive changes after a crappy friday night opening. END

BEGIN NOW     Aptly named and well-positioned, the latest addition to Broadway's booming West End is definitely lighting up the night. END
BEGIN NOW     From the stately facade with the carnival-esque lights and Wild Wild West signage to the warm glow of a slew of crystal chandeliers and wall sconces, The Night Light is beaming the modern-urban-oasis-meets-sexed-up-saloon vibe. END
BEGIN NOW     With vintage details abound, like the cash registers, the lush, leather club chairs, the bordello-esque wallpaper and boudoir paintings, the distinct crackle of vinyl over the Hi-Fi, and their own version of Miss Kitty (Miss Megan) behind the bar slingin' high-octane drinks, it's like a step back in time that is right ON time. END
BEGIN NOW     Makes sense coming from the former owners of The Ivy Room in Albany and Kitty's in Emeryville. END
BEGIN NOW      It's not their first trip to the rodeo, they do seem to know a thing or two about attracting and keeping a hip and loyal clientele. END

BEGIN NOW     This is really the only reason I go out after dark. END
BEGIN NOW      Which, granted, still doesn't happen as often as it should - there are regular awesome shows here featuring a bevy of great local garage bands upstairs, and some excellent DJs downstairs. END
BEGIN NOW      The decor is kind of stunning, the drinks are solid, the staff is a fantastic group of people. END
BEGIN NOW      Usually I'm wary of places that separate the stage/venue from the bar because there can be a weird dis-congruity between crowds, but it works pretty well here. END
BEGIN NOW      Even when there's a less-than-obvious show/DJ match up (like the psych-garage show with old-school hip-hop DJ night that'll pop up now and then) it still manages to feel comfortable moving back and forth, unlike the middle-school-dance complex many of these places can get (opposite sides of the room, *maybe* one or two brave souls crossing over to dance). END
BEGIN NOW     And in terms of service, yeah, it's a bar, sometimes you don't get your drink immediately. END
BEGIN NOW      But I'd rather be spending my Saturday night with good company and good drinks and good tunes than plop down somewhere where the bartender has nothing to do but sit in front of me and pour my bevvies. END
BEGIN NOW      If I'm just looking to get drunk quick I'll stay home. END

BEGIN NOW     Pro-tip 2: AC Transit late-night free shuttle b/t downtown &amp; JLS. END
BEGIN NOW     Pro-tip 3: Nations next door is open until 1, but no late-night breakfast. END

BEGIN NOW     This review is based on a happy hour visit and a Saturday night visit. END
BEGIN NOW     Aesthetically, Night Light harkens back to the 1920s. END
BEGIN NOW      The interior features a nicely finished wooden bar, and the alcohol is housed on brightly illuminated wooden shelving that frames a large mirror. END
BEGIN NOW      There are a number of bar stools for patrons looking to gaze at the alcohol (or themselves) while imbibing, yet not so many that you feel you're rubbing shoulders with the stranger next to you. END
BEGIN NOW      The rest of the surprisingly ample interior space comprises of a collection of comfortable (p)leather armchairs, loveseats, and side tables, all smartly arranged to accommodate smaller and larger groups. END
BEGIN NOW      The walls are wood paneled above a 1920s era wallpaper style, and an attractive chandelier and a couple of other ceiling lights dimly light the space. END
BEGIN NOW      All in all, it's an attractive, relaxing interior space. END
BEGIN NOW     Night Light seems to be going for the small-batch, artisanal alcohol program, much like the other newer bars over in the Uptown area. END
BEGIN NOW      The cocktail menu was solid, but no more interesting than the various other artisanal cocktail menus that are popping up like wildflowers. END
BEGIN NOW      I ordered a drink off the cocktail menu (the name of which escapes me), and it was quite tasty yet unbalanced; the smokiness of the single-malt scotch overpowered the other ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW      Either way, it was good enough that I ordered a second. END
BEGIN NOW      I also had a decent Manhattan. END
BEGIN NOW      Drink prices (cocktails ranged from $8 - $10) were very fair for a bar of this caliber. END
BEGIN NOW      They also had some beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW     The service was very good. END
BEGIN NOW      My bartender was attentive and very friendly. END
BEGIN NOW      I observed him trying to serve people in a first-come, first-served fashion, which I always appreciate. END
BEGIN NOW      A second bartender also seemed to have the right idea - she appeared friendly and efficient. END
BEGIN NOW     Bottom Line: Night Light is a solid newcomer in an increasingly crowded and competitive field. END
BEGIN NOW      While not without many merits, the drinks were not exceptional and (for me) it's a tad off the beaten path. END
BEGIN NOW      While I will definitely return and have already recommended Night Light to several people, it's not among the "best" bars Oakland has to offer. END

BEGIN NOW     "Oh, he's very popular Ed. END
BEGIN NOW      The sportos, the motorheads, geeks, sluts, bloods, wastoids, dweebies, dickheads - they all adore him. END
BEGIN NOW      They think he's a righteous dude. END
BEGIN NOW     "-- from "Ferris Bueller's Day Off"A visit to Heart &amp; Dagger often reminds me of these words. END
BEGIN NOW      As watering holes go, it may not be for every body, but it has a strikingly wide array of fans. END
BEGIN NOW      And for us fans, it holds a piece of our hearts. END
BEGIN NOW      The vibe is casual (read: 'divey'), distinctly Oakland, with a wild undercurrent befitting a David Lynch film. END
BEGIN NOW      A biker bar only 'modestly' gentrified by neo-Oaklandites/wannabees/over-incomed geeks, to which I confess a partial complicity. END
BEGIN NOW       The playground segments into roughly three arenas:  (1) Bar area, where the bees get their honey -- and the barkeeps, both efficient and commanding, do a great job keeping the drones and workers happy. END
BEGIN NOW      Beer specials and shots of liquor are an excellent value, especially during HH, when my lovely Bulliet Manhattans are especially generous. END
BEGIN NOW      (2) Patio, definitely favored by the dog-partnered and smoking clientele, and seems to collect the more regular patrons. END
BEGIN NOW      Gossip is overheard, smiles are witnessed, wafting cigarette smoke is inhaled. END
BEGIN NOW      Water from two giant ThermosTM coolers is free and easily accessed for both two and four-legged visitors back here. END
BEGIN NOW     And then there is (3), the pool table. END
BEGIN NOW       Where I learned, thanks to tutelage from billiards Maestro M and a few tips from other regulars, to now actually almost *not* suck at pool-playing. END
BEGIN NOW       Back to (3) in a bit. END
BEGIN NOW      For the bar en masse though: at its heart of gold though does push the tip of its dagger, as visits here have not always been a feel-good utopian experience. END
BEGIN NOW      I've seen people verbally insulted or kicked out for debatable reasons by the staff (actually mostly just one staff member, whose shifts are minimal); heard obnoxious comments by drunk and/or loud bigots; spied sketchy characters sporting knives in their back pocket, and witnessed a few "lively" disagreements over 8-ball. END
BEGIN NOW      Admittedly, H&amp;D is an onion with many layers, and not all those layers are pretty. END
BEGIN NOW       The trifling edginess is in reality as much an allure as a downer, and a metaphor and microcosm of our world and city and a reminder that good or bad you're still a part of it so why not be a positive part or at the very least learn how to deal with it? In reality, I don't wax all philosophic like that when I visit here. END
BEGIN NOW      Which brings us back to (3):  I do, truly, enjoy the regular pool players, and the competition and camaraderie I'm fortunate to have shared. END
BEGIN NOW       I'm a square peg for several reasons in H&amp;D, but the bonding with other such pegs or non-pegs is the reason I love to visit. END
BEGIN NOW      And on those visits, I get to practice my shot, nurse my bourbon, and inhale the simple sideways joys that life has to offer. END
BEGIN NOW     Can one sum up H&amp;D in a single catchphrase?  "All for one, one for all, just watch your wallet and drink. END
BEGIN NOW     " "You don't have to be a biker to come, but it don't hurt if you are one. END
BEGIN NOW     " "A bar of inimitable substance and a multitude of substances. END
BEGIN NOW     " Nah . END
BEGIN NOW      screw that. END
BEGIN NOW      Heart and Dagger defies an easy Yelp review description. END
BEGIN NOW      And I'm guessing they like it that way. END
BEGIN NOW      Just be chill, be respectful, be unorthodox, be free, and be yourself. END
BEGIN NOW      It's not to be analyzed. END
BEGIN NOW      Just enjoyed. END
BEGIN NOW     If you like dive bars without the meth mouth, Sons of Anarchy watching patrons, Heart and Dagger will sit very well with you. END

BEGIN NOW     Cosecha is a Mexican eatery with a nouvelle California twist. END
BEGIN NOW      It's located inside old Oakland's Swan's Market. END
BEGIN NOW      Solid wooden benches-- amenable to communal style seating -- are set up in front of their ordering counter. END
BEGIN NOW      I actually love shared dining like this; seems only fitting for a 'market' context. END
BEGIN NOW     The open wall aspect of this market is attractive; chose to avoid the interior ceiling fans and be warmed by the direct sun. END
BEGIN NOW      People sitting outside were accompanied by their pets. END
BEGIN NOW      The ordering line took just a bit of time. END
BEGIN NOW      I loved observing the hustle and bustle of the open prep station behind the glass. END
BEGIN NOW       While waiting in line, I perused the paper menu pasted onto the glass counter. END
BEGIN NOW       I was there towards the end of weekend brunch (they close at 3:00 p. END
BEGIN NOW     m. END
BEGIN NOW     ) I ordered the wild shrimp tacos and the horchata latte, following the tip from Bon Appetit's August 2015 issue which featured Oakland dining spots including Cosecha. END
BEGIN NOW       Place your order at the counter and pay, then servers bring your food out. END
BEGIN NOW       The horchata latte was sheer cinnamon-y goodness served in a tall glass-- light, sweet, and tinged with coffee tones. END
BEGIN NOW       I thought it would be the perfect non-dairy counterpoint to spicy Mexican chillies. END
BEGIN NOW       The two corn tortillas piled high with batter-fried shrimp were nicely presented. END
BEGIN NOW      The shrimp sat on shredded cabbage, were topped with a chili-infused crema sauce and garnished with jalapeno and cilantro. END
BEGIN NOW      The tacos weren't spicy and the cup of beans on the side were well-flavored. END
BEGIN NOW      The shrimp were high quality and fresh with a firm bite (none of the mealy texture of aquaculture-produced shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW     ) My only gripe might be the quantity size--too small. END
BEGIN NOW       The prices will reveal that this is not another street-stall taco shop although it functions like one. END
BEGIN NOW      I paid around $15 for the gourmet, delicately flavored shrimp. END
BEGIN NOW       This place offers sufficiently unique taste that it's worth a special treat, but it wouldn't be my daily go-to, based on price alone. END
BEGIN NOW       There are plenty of more ordinary tacquerias for everyday dining. END

BEGIN NOW      The interior was fully cooked but it was still moist and tender. END
BEGIN NOW      I added the cajeta sauce which is a Mexican-style caramel. END
BEGIN NOW      So good, I was literally scraping the tiny container for every last drop. END

BEGIN NOW      As a restaurant, you live and die by your patrons. END

BEGIN NOW     To me, it is hard to find a fabulous Mexican food/restaurant. END

BEGIN NOW      It's usually always the same. END

BEGIN NOW      The family would get together and cook big regional meals from old family recipes. END

BEGIN NOW     The Chicken Mole Verde was fantastic (not your typical mole sauce made with chocolate). END
BEGIN NOW      Consecha's sauce had a little bit of bite/heat to it, but it was spicy without burning your mouth, and without lasting effect. END

BEGIN NOW     I've been on the hunt for really good Mexican food since moving to the bay area - living in San Diego (aka, California's Best Border Town) spoiled me rotten. END
BEGIN NOW      There I was treated to the best guacamole and fish tacos north of Mexico. END
BEGIN NOW      When I heard about Cosecha, I was over the moon. END
BEGIN NOW      but while my high expectations probably weren't very helpful, this was definitely not a 5-star experience. END
BEGIN NOW      The restaurant is buried in a warehouse maze - an interesting space, just a liiiiittle hard to navigate. END
BEGIN NOW      We had a table reserved, thanks to a friend who plans ahead - but there was no one available to ask about said table. END
BEGIN NOW      There was 1 server running around like a madwoman, and 1 guy at the cash register taking/filling orders, but no one else. END
BEGIN NOW      People were wandering around uncertain as to whether they should seat themselves or wait to be seated. END
BEGIN NOW      we finally went to the wine store next door (which has no door/sign/anything marking it as a separate entity) hoping to get our questions answers. END
BEGIN NOW      The place just seemed completely disorganized. END
BEGIN NOW     So here's how it works! It's family-style self-seating at long picnic tables, unless you make a reservation, and then you can get a private table in the back. END
BEGIN NOW      If you wait for a server to seat you or come to your table, you'll wait forever - order at the front counter, by the register. END
BEGIN NOW      The menu &amp; specials are listed on a chalkboard on the wall, but beware: we'd come for the night's special, wild shrimp tacos, but they were sold out by 6pm. END
BEGIN NOW      We were baffled - it was early and the place wasn't even crowded. END
BEGIN NOW      Not cool to sell out of your Dinner Special at the beginning of dinnertime. END
BEGIN NOW      They also need more staff on the floor - for 40 minutes we had water but no glasses. END
BEGIN NOW      Which went well with our chicken/pork tortillas that were missing tortillas. END
BEGIN NOW     The food was good - the kind of good you're psyched to eat, but not the kind of good you'd return for. END
BEGIN NOW      We tried the grilled chicken achiote - chicken marinated in achiote with rice, beans &amp; handmade tortillas, and the carne adovada - braised pork with chile guajillo, beans, rice &amp; tortillas. END
BEGIN NOW      Really good guacamole!! The tortillas were handmade and delicious; the rest of the dish was fresh but unremarkable. END
BEGIN NOW      The people who work here are incredibly nice - but they're also really overwhelmed. END
BEGIN NOW      Maybe now that Cosecha is so popular, they'll make it more user friendly. END

BEGIN NOW     Fun place in Oakland! I came here for dinner with friends after a day of drinking our way through Napa. END

BEGIN NOW     Lively, quality gastropub that's helping to put the area around 40th Street and Broadway on the map as a new dining corridor in Oakland, with a feel and identity that's distinct from gentrified Piedmont Avenue not far away. END
BEGIN NOW     The first things you notice are the tremendous craft beer selection and the meat/pork-heavy menu. END
BEGIN NOW      As for the beer, the selection is quite extensive and although it features mostly craft brews, it looks like it's been curated to be very comprehensive across all major styles. END
BEGIN NOW      Moreover, if you have any questions about any single beer item, you could ask for a little taste, or you could ask for advice on what pairs well with certain dishes on the menu. END
BEGIN NOW     And as for the menu, it is quite meat-heavy (although I assume some items may be vegetarian-friendly or can be made so). END
BEGIN NOW      While items like sausages might sound steep at around $13, the portion size is tremendous, and the case of the "Got Seoul" sausage that they offered recently, it comes topped uniquely with Asian ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW      There are even meatier, more substantial entrees available too, all with whimsical names to them. END
BEGIN NOW      Everything is so meaty and delicious, you'll be "mmm"-ing with approval throughout the meal. END
BEGIN NOW     The overall atmosphere is quite friendly and festive, with lots of communal seating, and the place can be packed most of the time. END
BEGIN NOW      Service is also knowledgeable and friendly too. END
BEGIN NOW      Chalk up another win for the 40th Street area and for the Oakland dining scene. END

BEGIN NOW     My girlfriend and I went on a double date with two of our friends, and we had dinner at The Hog's Apothecary. END
BEGIN NOW      It was a Saturday night, and there was a good crowd. END
BEGIN NOW      This restaurant has communal tables which is something that I absolutely disdain. END
BEGIN NOW      As someone who has a busy schedule and is in a long distance relationship, my time with my girlfriend, my friends, and my family is precious to me. END
BEGIN NOW      When I finally get the time to spend with my self-selected company, I hate having to shout over strangers to avoid being drowned out by their own conversations. END
BEGIN NOW      That being said, the communal tables at Hog's were not nearly as cramped as the ones at Homeroom. END
BEGIN NOW      You still have to do a lot of yelling though. END
BEGIN NOW      The hard wooden benches were pretty uncomfortable too. END
BEGIN NOW      Everything else about the restaurant was really great though. END
BEGIN NOW      They offer a preponderance of great local and semi-local beers on tap. END
BEGIN NOW      I had the Buddha's Hand IPA from Berryessa Brewing in Winters, CA, and it was awesome. END
BEGIN NOW      It was not overly bitter and had a pleasant citrus taste from the Buddha's hand. END
BEGIN NOW      Everyone else enjoyed their beers as well. END
BEGIN NOW     My girlfriend and I started our meal with a soft pretzel. END
BEGIN NOW      The pretzel had a rich, brown skin and was light and airy on the inside. END
BEGIN NOW      I really enjoyed the spicy mustard dipping sauce that came with the pretzel. END
BEGIN NOW      The heat from the mustard hits you right in the sinuses (in a good way). END
BEGIN NOW     For our meal, we shared the corn dog and the Jamaican Me Crazy sausage. END
BEGIN NOW     Corn dog: Easily one of the best (non-State Fair) corn dogs I've ever had. END
BEGIN NOW      However, I feel like corn dogs are kind of like donuts. END
BEGIN NOW      Awful ones are still pretty good, and even the best version with the best possible ingredients is only a few times better than the average ones. END
BEGIN NOW      Jamaican Me Crazy: The sausage was tasty, although the jerk seasoning could have been a little more bold. END
BEGIN NOW      I only tasted faint traces of allspice. END
BEGIN NOW      The bun pillow-soft and provided a textural contrast to the pop I would get when biting into the casing of the sausage. END
BEGIN NOW      The potato chips were tasty too. END
BEGIN NOW      While both items were really good, they do seem a little overpriced for what they are. END
BEGIN NOW     Our service was good, although there was some redundancy between the servers. END

BEGIN NOW      They got it right eventually though. END
BEGIN NOW     Overall, I like The Hog's Apothecary and would come back another time for beer and a corn dog. END

BEGIN NOW     With a menu that is constantly changing, Hog's Apothecary has a lot to offer, even if the day's menu isn't super extensive - roughly a dozen starters and sides, a handful of sausages, and a few different entrées. END
BEGIN NOW       What's more, there's beer and lots of it. END

BEGIN NOW     -- SPICY PORK CRACKLIN'S. END
BEGIN NOW     $3(yelp. END
BEGIN NOW     com/biz_photos/the-…)These cracklin's are crackin'!  Not only are they borderline addictive, but they really do pack some heat, as every piece is coated with a spicy, mouth-watering seasoning (don't forget the lime!). END
BEGIN NOW       What's more, the portion is quite generous!  A great starter for groups to share. END

BEGIN NOW     $6(yelp. END

BEGIN NOW       If this isn't the best one I've had, it wouldn't be far behind. END
BEGIN NOW     -- SUPERFECTA SAUSAGE SANDWICH - Pork, Rabbit, Chicken, Tim's Brown Ale, Basque Chili &amp; Mild Herbs, Fennel-Onion Braise, Dijon Mustard. END

BEGIN NOW       Great food otherwise, an awesome selection of beers, fantastic staff (they let our large party split our bill into smaller tabs), and (relatively) easy parking. END
BEGIN NOW       Plus, with several long tables, Hog's Apothecary is grew for groups large or small. END

BEGIN NOW     When going to the restaurant of a friend for the first time, one prepares themselves to be polite, offering words of praise out of the sense of duty that comes with being friends. END
BEGIN NOW       We caution ourselves not to be harsh or critical and generally keep any negatives quiet. END
BEGIN NOW       After all, they are our friends and we'd expect the same. END
BEGIN NOW     Thank goodness I don't have to keep the negatives to myself. END
BEGIN NOW       as I couldn't find any. END
BEGIN NOW       In fact, to say I was impressed would be an understatement. END
BEGIN NOW     Brad and John have taken what once was a dilapidated laundromat with a seedy past and created a neighborhood gathering spot that is open, airy and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW       I was at first slightly put off by the long tables and benches, as I generally prefer not to share my table with people I don't know, but I came to realize that it promotes conversation between strangers and contributes to the neighborhood feel. END
BEGIN NOW       While the dining area is not huge, the high ceiling with exposed beams and open air skylight make it feel much larger. END
BEGIN NOW       "Hog's" boasts more taps than I could get through in a week. END
BEGIN NOW       They have beers on tap to appeal to any beer drinker. END
BEGIN NOW       They also cycle beers in and out to keep the selections new and inviting. END
BEGIN NOW       Now. END
BEGIN NOW      on to the food itself. END
BEGIN NOW       We started out with the warm pretzel for two with cheese sauce and mustard. END
BEGIN NOW      ( One thing you must know before I go further. END
BEGIN NOW       Nearly everything you eat is made in house. END
BEGIN NOW       The mustard, the cheese, the sausage, the kraut. END
BEGIN NOW       the exceptions being the buns and, if memory serves, the pretzel itself. END
BEGIN NOW      )  The pretzel was hot and delicious. END
BEGIN NOW       The house made mustard and cheese sauce were the perfect compliment. END
BEGIN NOW       There's just no comparison between jar mustard and mustard made fresh that day. END
BEGIN NOW       For my entree I ordered the schnitzel. END
BEGIN NOW       It's really easy to overcook pork and make it dry. END
BEGIN NOW       Not the case here. END
BEGIN NOW       The breading was light, the pork juicy and while I used my knife at first, I ended up using just my fork as it was so tender. END
BEGIN NOW       The arugula and warm potato salad only served to enhance the succulent pork. END
BEGIN NOW       My dining companions ordered the 'Basa' with kraut and the Devil Bird fried chicken. END
BEGIN NOW       I was raised by a German mother who made ( and at 70 still makes ) her own kraut. END
BEGIN NOW      As much as I cannot believe I am saying this, ( Sorry, Mom ) the kraut at Hog's is better. END
BEGIN NOW       especially thrown on top of a juicy and savory sausage with just the right pop from the casing. END
BEGIN NOW       ( Sorry, Mom ) The chicken was juicy and full of flavor, but it's the breading that really takes it over the top. END
BEGIN NOW       It's hard to describe, but there's a slight sweetness to it that, to me, was reminiscent of that first bite of a churro or a Krispy Kreme that immediately makes you want another bite. END
BEGIN NOW       It's difficult NOT to want to clean your plate. END
BEGIN NOW     I do have one regret. END
BEGIN NOW       Only one. END
BEGIN NOW       I didn't try dessert. END
BEGIN NOW       We all surveyed the dessert menu, but after a great beer and amazing food there was just no room. END
BEGIN NOW     I know I am a friend and friends tend to be biased so I encourage you to read other reviews. END
BEGIN NOW       Aside from the small contingent of nay-sayers you will find that the overall rating of 4/5 stars is well earned and well deserved. END
BEGIN NOW       It's worth checking out. END

BEGIN NOW     Fun place in Oakland! I came here for dinner with friends after a day of drinking our way through Napa. END

BEGIN NOW     Lively, quality gastropub that's helping to put the area around 40th Street and Broadway on the map as a new dining corridor in Oakland, with a feel and identity that's distinct from gentrified Piedmont Avenue not far away. END
BEGIN NOW     The first things you notice are the tremendous craft beer selection and the meat/pork-heavy menu. END
BEGIN NOW      As for the beer, the selection is quite extensive and although it features mostly craft brews, it looks like it's been curated to be very comprehensive across all major styles. END
BEGIN NOW      Moreover, if you have any questions about any single beer item, you could ask for a little taste, or you could ask for advice on what pairs well with certain dishes on the menu. END
BEGIN NOW     And as for the menu, it is quite meat-heavy (although I assume some items may be vegetarian-friendly or can be made so). END
BEGIN NOW      While items like sausages might sound steep at around $13, the portion size is tremendous, and the case of the "Got Seoul" sausage that they offered recently, it comes topped uniquely with Asian ingredients. END
BEGIN NOW      There are even meatier, more substantial entrees available too, all with whimsical names to them. END
BEGIN NOW      Everything is so meaty and delicious, you'll be "mmm"-ing with approval throughout the meal. END
BEGIN NOW     The overall atmosphere is quite friendly and festive, with lots of communal seating, and the place can be packed most of the time. END
BEGIN NOW      Service is also knowledgeable and friendly too. END
BEGIN NOW      Chalk up another win for the 40th Street area and for the Oakland dining scene. END
